[16:24:00.0000] <jwalden>
so, looking at the websocket protocol, what constraints are enforced on the server regarding processing of the input?  is it an error if tab-delimited "header" lines are received?  what if "multi-line headers" are received?  basically, websockets looks like HTTP, but at what point does accepting HTTP input that's more lax than the websocket client input constitute a violation of the protocol...

[16:24:01.0000] <jwalden>
...requirements?

[16:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
what do you mean by "enforced"?

[16:26:01.0000] <Hixie>
the protocol spec says what you're expected to suport

[16:26:02.0000] <Hixie>
support

[16:26:03.0000] <Hixie>
as a server-side author

[16:27:00.0000] <jwalden>
s/enforced/required/, then

[16:27:01.0000] <jwalden>
the client is required to follow the exact steps given in the draft

[16:27:02.0000] <Hixie>
http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-hixie-thewebsocketprotocol-12#page-15

[16:28:00.0000] <jwalden>
the server, it seems, has latitude to accept more than that

[16:28:01.0000] <jwalden>
is the server required to accept input from a client that doesn't actually follow the strictures of the client-processing section?

[16:28:02.0000] <jwalden>
yes, I've been looking at that

[16:29:00.0000] <ezyang>
gsnedders: My idea is to implement SimpleTree and watch our performance problems melt away ^_^ 

[16:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
jwalden: the server doesn't have to do any error handling, if that's what you mean

[16:29:02.0000] <jwalden>
okay

[16:30:00.0000] <jwalden>
that seems...dangerous

[16:30:01.0000] <jwalden>
not in any tangible sense

[16:30:02.0000] <Hixie>
the ability to control authors is basically nil

[16:30:03.0000] <Hixie>
so getting them to implement particular error handling behavior... forget it

[16:30:04.0000] <jwalden>
but in the sense of I-can-plausibly-believe-this-will-bite-us-at-some-point

[16:30:05.0000] <jwalden>
no, this is error handling server-side

[16:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
right

[16:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
authors write the server side

[16:31:02.0000] <jwalden>
oh, there are authors on both sides

[16:31:03.0000] <jwalden>
hum, this might work then

[16:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
i could write a new section

[16:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
which is "full requirements for server-side implementors that actually follow specs"

[16:32:02.0000] <Hixie>
if you like

[16:32:03.0000] <Hixie>
might not be a bad idea

[16:32:04.0000] <jwalden>
dunno, yet

[16:32:05.0000] <Hixie>
if you do think that would be useful, send a mail to whatwg, and i'll add it

[16:33:00.0000] <jwalden>
I'm just looking at this from the POV of the Mozilla bug, in which our HTTP server is being lightly hijacked to support all this, worried about being more generous in accepting input than it should be

[16:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
is this for testing or for production?

[16:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
for regression testing, it doesn't matter what the server does, it just has to check that the client sends exactly the right bytes

[16:34:01.0000] <jwalden>
I try not to differentiate the two when I write servers (or rather, when I write the one server I've written so far)

[16:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
a regression test suite server and a production server are completely different

[16:34:03.0000] <Hixie>
you can't, e.g., use apache to do serious regression testing of client-side http behaviour

[16:34:04.0000] <jwalden>
yes, but that doesn't mean one shouldn't make an effort not to make it safe-by-default

[16:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't really see how a regression-testing server framework can be unsafe -- it has to accept any input whatsoever

[16:36:00.0000] <jwalden>
hm, I think we're talking about different meanings; "production" to me is use in which inputs are unconstrained, "regression-testing" in the sense of inputs are constrained but may intentionally be random junk

[16:36:01.0000] <jwalden>
constrained by whatever's in the test suite using it

[16:40:00.0000] <jwalden>
on an unrelated note, reading RFC-style formatting rather than whatwg-style formatting is no fun :-(

[16:40:01.0000] <jwalden>
especially since things like "find" don't work due to ASCII text-decorations

[16:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
jwalden: an "in production" server is one serving end-user traffic

[16:42:01.0000] <jwalden>
we agree on that

[16:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
jwalden: a regression testing server is one used to test another tool's implementation

[16:43:00.0000] <jwalden>
sure, just say that I like my regression testing servers to have as rigorous an implementation as a production server must have

[16:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
so an in-production server can do things like disconnect if the input is bogus

[16:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
but a regression testing server needs to report pass/fail for all inputs

[20:49:00.0000] <boblet>
Hey all, I’d like to ask about the id attribute ‘opaque strings’ comment (3.3.3.1); what is meant by ‘Particular meanings should not be derived from the value of the id attribute’? Is this intended for browser makers?

[20:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
yes

[20:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
it means that id="header" doesn't mean the element is a header

[20:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
it could just as easily be a footer, or a link, or a duck

[20:51:00.0000] <boblet>
aah, that makes sense. So as authors we’d be encouraged to use meaningful names (as the class attribute spec specifically states), but that meaning shouldn’t affect how the browser treats the element with the id huh

[20:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[20:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
if you can come up with a better way for the spec to say that, drop me a line :-)

[20:54:00.0000] <boblet>
How would this sit with eg microformats? eg if the text specifically said “User agents should not derive particular meanings from the value of the id attribute” (which would remove the ambiguity for me), wouldn’t this also be problematic for eg Operator, Optimus et al?

[20:55:00.0000] <boblet>
Hrm, perhaps adding your example “eg id="header" should not be interpreted as <header>” is clearest?

[20:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
do they use id="" attribute values?

[20:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'd rather not define things by examples, though i could certainly _add_ examples if you want

[20:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
drop me a mail if you do

[21:01:00.0000] <boblet>
Microformats plugins/bookmarklets just look for the matching value, which could be class="vcard" or id="vcard". Using class="" is most common, but it’s possible an author might use id="". I’ll email you these comments. Thanks for the clarification

[21:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
k

[00:37:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
i just don't get why every time we find the need to create new technologies, someone says "you're ignoring the don't reinvent the wheel principle", especially when we documented why we were doing so for that feature

[01:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
or why every time any one principle is overriden by some other concern, people assume that means we should always ignore that principle

[01:52:01.0000] <Hixie>

[01:52:02.0000] <Hixie>

[01:52:03.0000] <Hixie>

[01:53:00.0000] <Hixie>

[08:02:00.0000] <Lachy>
calling Constructor() without "new" is just a regular function call

[08:02:01.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy_: That's the point

[08:02:02.0000] <jgraham>
function Construct() {this.a = 2}; b = Construct()

[08:02:03.0000] <jgraham>
Sets a global variable a to 2

[08:04:00.0000] <Lachy>
as an example of a completely backwards and unintuitive feature in python, to join an array of strings with some delimiter, instead of calling array.join(delim), you have to call "delim".join(array)

[08:05:00.0000] <Lachy>
and they use weird names like lists and dictionaries instead of array

[08:06:00.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: I thought that was crazy untill I realised that doing an operation on a string and getting a string back is more consistent than doing an operation on an array and getting a string back

[08:07:00.0000] <Lachy>
no, doing an operation on the object itself (an array in this case) to obtain some output makes much more sense from an object oriented programming perspective

[08:07:01.0000] <jgraham>

[08:25:00.0000] <Philip`>

[08:26:00.0000] <jgraham>

[08:26:01.0000] <Philip`>

[08:28:00.0000] <Lachy>
the underlying technical implementation is really irrelevant to whether or not it's an array

[08:30:00.0000] <Lachy>

[08:30:01.0000] <Philip`>

[08:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
and people should understand the distinctions, so they don't write silly code that has terrible performance

[08:42:00.0000] <gsnedders>
What should "<a a=a&>" output?

[08:42:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(From the tokenizer)

[08:47:00.0000] <gsnedders>
"If no match can be made, then no characters are consumed, and nothing is returned. If the current state is not the character reference in attribute value state, or the U+0026 AMPERSAND character is not followed by one or more characters in the ranges U+0030 DIGIT ZERO to U+0039 DIGIT NINE, U+0041 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A to U+005A LATIN CAPITAL LETTER Z, and U+0061 LATIN SMALL LETTER A to U+007A LATIN SMALL LETTER Z, fo

[08:47:01.0000] <gsnedders>
by a U+003D EQUALS SIGN character (=), then this is also a parse error."

[08:47:02.0000] <gsnedders>
That really doesn't read well.

[08:49:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:49:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Wrong way round.

[08:50:00.0000] <gsnedders>
"&foo=" is not a parse error, "&foo>" is.

[08:52:00.0000] <gsnedders>
"<a a=a&>" is right in the test, my impl. is not.

[12:41:01.0000] <jwalden>

[12:41:02.0000] <jgraham>

[12:42:01.0000] <jwalden>

[12:43:01.0000] <jgraham>

[12:45:00.0000] <jgraham>

[12:45:01.0000] <jwalden>

[12:45:02.0000] <jwalden>
I've stared long and hard at the array-index-property parts of es3

[12:46:00.0000] <jwalden>
frankly, arrays-as-objects is probably a bigger problem for implementations than for developers, since the convert-to-sparse determination is unspecified but necessary for performance and constraining memory use

[12:49:00.0000] <jwalden>
it's also a compatibility concern: SpiderMonkey has specifically tweaked its thresholds to perform better on certain JS benchmarks promulgated by the authors of engines which have different thresholds that don't fall over on said tests

[12:49:01.0000] <jwalden>
I do so love benchmarketing

[12:51:00.0000] <jwalden>
(threshold for sparsifying, to be clear, although I would be surprised if others haven't been similarly tweaked)

[12:52:00.0000] <jgraham>

[12:53:00.0000] <jwalden>
this wasn't "excessive" amounts of time, though, it was time measured in dozens of milliseconds

[12:53:01.0000] <jwalden>
efficiently storing array properties is faster than doing a generic property-hash-storage system, but it's not order-of-magnitude slower, not enough for authors to get confused about it

[12:54:00.0000] <jgraham>

[12:57:00.0000] <jwalden>

[19:42:01.0000] <Hixie>

[19:42:02.0000] <Hixie>

[19:42:03.0000] <Hixie>

[19:42:04.0000] <Hixie>

[19:42:05.0000] <Hixie>

[19:43:00.0000] <Hixie>

[06:53:00.0000] <Philip`>

[06:53:01.0000] <Philip`>
which says you need either Z or [+-]\d\d:\d\d

[07:32:01.0000] <ezyang>

[07:33:00.0000] <ezyang>

[07:34:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:35:03.0000] <Philip`>
HTML is consistent - you parse a sequence of non-whitespace characters and use that as the attribute name, and that's it (and you don't put the attribute into any particular namespace)

[13:13:00.0000] <atwilson>
I'm somewhat confused about the language surrounding task sources in section 6.5.4 - in particular, if an object is no longer used as a task source for an event loop (for example, a MessagePort that has been closed, does that imply that all queued (but not yet dispatched) events for that task source are removed from the queue?

[13:13:01.0000] <atwilson>
Anyone know what behavior is intended?

[13:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
atwilson: why would that cause it to no longer be used?

[13:17:00.0000] <atwilson>
Ah.

[13:17:01.0000] <atwilson>
I read this: When a port's port message queue is open, the event loop must use it as one of its task sources. and assumed that causing close() would also close the message queue, but apparently that is not the case.

[13:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
nope

[13:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
i should probably make that clearer

[13:18:02.0000] <atwilson>
Close just prevents the ports from communicating with one another, but doesn't affect the open status of the queues.

[13:18:03.0000] <Hixie>
maybe use different words than open/close

[13:20:00.0000] <atwilson>
Yeah, maybe. The spec pretty clearly doesn't say that the message queue is closed - that was entirely my misreading, although I guess explicitly stating that the port message queue should be left open wouldn't be bad.

[13:20:01.0000] <zcorpan>
"W3C: Web Storage draft standard" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOM_storage

[13:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
atwilson: i've reowrded it to say "enabled" vs" disabled" and to mention that it never goes back to disabled

[13:22:01.0000] <atwilson>
Hixie: OK. Note that it *does* go back to disabled if the port is cloned.

[13:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
actually no, it just gets emptied

[13:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
this has much the same effect, of course

[13:23:01.0000] <atwilson>
Ah, you are right again.

[13:23:02.0000] <Hixie>
i have an unfair advantage in that i wrote this nonsense :-)

[13:23:03.0000] <Hixie>
sadly i still sometimes find i wrote something that i didn't think i wrote :-(

[13:24:00.0000] <atwilson>
Anyhow, I like having the port never go back to disabled. Thanks for clarifying.

[01:12:00.0000] <annevk42>

[01:12:02.0000] <heycam>

[01:13:00.0000] <hsivonen>
heycam: tough luck

[01:14:00.0000] <hsivonen>
heycam: actually, there's a way

[01:15:00.0000] <hsivonen>
heycam: 1) make all your MathML text nodes into CDATA sections

[01:16:00.0000] <hsivonen>
heycam: 2) stick and <img> with the image of the formula into annotation-xml

[01:16:01.0000] <hsivonen>
heycam: 3) hide annotation-xml using a selector that has an explicit namespace so it only matches if the elements really got assigned to the MathML namespace

[01:17:00.0000] <heycam>
that's so crazy it just might work

[01:17:01.0000] <Philip`>

[01:18:00.0000] <heycam>

[05:36:00.0000] <jgraham>

[05:36:01.0000] <jgraham>

[05:36:02.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: tokenizer

[05:37:00.0000] <jgraham>

[05:37:01.0000] <jgraham>

[05:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me really ought to update his tokeniser / test generator

[05:39:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Where is the code? I have no intentions to make changes I just want to know if it makes more sense to me than last time I looked at it...

[05:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: There's some version at http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/svn/tokeniser/ which might (or might not) be close to the latest version that exists

[05:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
test_gen.ml is the bit that generates tests, based on the interpreter in tokeniser_interp.ml which executes the algorithm in tokeniser_spec.ml

[05:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, I'm not entirely certain that any of it makes sense to me

[05:46:00.0000] <hsivonen>
the tokenizer alone seems to have over 50 different errors and warnings

[05:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think test_gen basically has a list of test strings (initially [""]), then for each one it looks at the final interpreter state (just before it would consume an EOF) and finds all the 'interesting' characters for that state, and then constructs a new set of strings, and then trims out ones that end up in duplicate states of others, and then repeats a few times

[05:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: What kinds of errors?

[05:49:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: I mean the number of different error messages the V.nu tokenizer can emit

[05:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: Oh, right

[08:04:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:04:02.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:05:00.0000] <ezyang>

[08:06:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:06:01.0000] <ezyang>

[08:07:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:07:01.0000] <ezyang>

[12:17:06.0000] <shelleyp>
mpilgrim: but it doesn't have the same scale on the web as div

[12:17:07.0000] <mpilgrim>
although you may have heard that we (google) pre-announced our make-SVG-work-in-IE javascript library

[12:18:00.0000] <rubys>

[12:18:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
yes

[12:18:02.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:18:03.0000] <shelleyp>
@hober: I don't agree with you. You're saying that unless an arbitrary percentage of sites use @summary, it's "failed"

[12:18:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
no

[12:18:05.0000] <mpilgrim>
that is not what we're saying

[12:19:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
you have to look at the percentage of people who use it

[12:19:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
the percentage of people who use it properly

[12:19:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
and the percentage of people who should use it, but aren't

[12:19:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
that's the problem with @summary and @longdesc

[12:19:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
it's not useful for most images

[12:19:05.0000] <mpilgrim>
it's frequently abused (i.e. wikipedia abused it for many years)

[12:19:06.0000] <mpilgrim>
it's frequently misused

[12:19:07.0000] <shelleyp>
But people are capable of learning, both from mistakes and from other people's successful efforts

[12:20:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
yes

[12:20:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
individuals are capable of learning

[12:20:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
groups are not

[12:20:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
(much)

[12:21:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
and (finishing my thought on @summary) most of the images that should be using it, don't

[12:21:01.0000] <shelleyp>
Returning to the topic, specifically @summary, where is the "harm" in its use?

[12:21:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
even if you educated every single blind person (the alleged target audience for the feature), they wouldn't ever run into a proper use of it

[12:21:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
except in accessibility tutorials

[12:22:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
the harm has also been explained

[12:22:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
i'll ignore the cost to implementers and other non-blind people for now

[12:22:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
focusing strictly on blind web users

[12:23:00.0000] <rubys>
summarizing:" summary has been around for a number of years, by this point whether it works or not should not be a matter of assertion from first principles, but from actual measurements.  Key questions to be answered: who should use summary?  are they?  If not, why not?  what should user agents do with summary?  are they?  If not, why not?"  Is that a fair summary?

[12:23:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
if the feature is frequently abused or misused, then blind people are just being bombarded with crap

[12:23:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
accessi-spam, as it were

[12:24:00.0000] <shelleyp>
Unfortunately, blind people are most likely bombarded with crap on a regular basis -- including tables for layout

[12:24:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
if there is a real problem (navigating complex tables), and if @summary is put forth as the ONE TRUE WAY to solve that problem,

[12:24:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
then blind people are being harmed by the missed opportunity of a better solution

[12:24:03.0000] <shelleyp>
So what's your solution? 

[12:24:04.0000] <rubys>

[12:24:05.0000] <mpilgrim>
i'm not saying i have an easy solution

[12:24:06.0000] <hober>
rubys: basically, yes. after ten years, we can be empiricists.  as tantek said, http://twitter.com/t/status/318565892

[12:24:07.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:25:03.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:26:00.0000] <rubys>

[12:26:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
that would actively dissuade people from attempting a better solution

[12:26:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
my point is, i acknowledge that some images are complex enough to require further explanation

[12:26:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
beyond a short phrase

[12:27:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
i acknowledge that some tables are complex enough to warrant a description of their structure

[12:27:01.0000] <rubys>
the problem is that there is a growing perception that no matter how good the answers given are, they will never be "good enough" as the goalposts are always being raised.

[12:27:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
but for many years, the only people trying to solve these problems were only interested in solving them for themselves

[12:27:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
with accessibility-specific markup

[12:27:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
which doesn't scale

[12:27:05.0000] <mpilgrim>
across the world wide web of authors

[12:28:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
(unless you're serious about stabbing 100 million people in the eyes)

[12:28:01.0000] <shelleyp>

[12:28:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
that mindset is the problem

[12:28:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
it's why we're talking past each other

[12:28:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
one side says "if the image is so complex, wouldn't everyone benefit from a longer description of it?"

[12:29:00.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:29:01.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:29:02.0000] <shelleyp>

[12:29:03.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:29:04.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:29:05.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:29:06.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:29:07.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:30:00.0000] <shelleyp>

[12:30:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
and now i don't believe that

[12:30:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
in fact, i believe that accessibility-specific markup is actively harmful to accessibility

[12:30:03.0000] <rubys>
ah, now I finally see an answer to the question shelley actually asked

[12:30:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
and the more specific the use case, the more harmful it gets

[12:30:05.0000] <shelleyp>
rubys raised a point: there is a growing perception that no matter how many answers are provided, they'll never enough

[12:31:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
no one has demonstrated why accessibility-specific markup is the right solution

[12:31:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
they just keep repeating it

[12:31:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
they take it on faith that it is

[12:31:03.0000] <hober>
I think something slightly weaker is true: accessibility-specific markup whose contents aren't shown to users not using AT, that's the harmful kind of markup

[12:31:04.0000] <inimino>
would that include @alt?

[12:31:05.0000] <hober>
E.g., seems like @aria-describedby would be much better than @summary

[12:31:06.0000] <shelleyp>

[12:31:07.0000] <mpilgrim>
@alt is the most successful of a very weak lot

[12:31:08.0000] <hober>
(assuming the element pointed at is visible to everyone)

[12:32:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
measured in absolute terms, it has been a miserable failure

[12:32:01.0000] <shelleyp>

[12:32:02.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:32:03.0000] <mpilgrim>

[12:32:04.0000] <hober>

[12:33:02.0000] <mpilgrim>

[13:21:00.0000] <tantek>

[13:22:00.0000] <Hixie>

[13:22:01.0000] <shelleyp>

[13:22:02.0000] <shelleyp>

[13:22:03.0000] <Hixie>
(research shows that summary="" isn't actually solving the problem that needs solving here; therefore we need something better. various people, including some from the US gov't's accessibility teams, have concluded that <caption> is an overall better solution.)

[13:23:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, basing judgments on research rather than unqualified opinions *is* a scientific method.

[13:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: to some extent, yes; but some people (e.g. rubys earlier) believe that it means you can come up with a single test the result of which can directly drive language design without a subjective component

[13:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
which is clearly not the case

[13:24:02.0000] <Hixie>
you have to interpret the results of any study

[13:24:03.0000] <tantek>
shelleyp, Hixie certainly applied "scientific thinking ...  observations, questions, multiple hypotheses, and more observations." to the table summary issue, per the cited 601.html email.

[13:24:04.0000] <tantek>
(quote excerpted from "Science is a progress" link above)

[13:25:00.0000] <shelleyp>

[13:25:01.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, I'm not sure of the "single test" hypothesis either - that's why I simply asked for alternative scientific analyses, at least as rigorous as your 601.html

[13:25:02.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: right

[13:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
shelleyp: no one test could be used for something that big, the microdata section involved hundreds of individual decisions each of which had to be based on research, implementation experience, discussions with authors, etc

[13:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
shelleyp: for example, to test whether the microdata features as described actually solved the problems they set out to solve, i explicitly used them to do so

[13:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
shelleyp: (most of that isn't documented in the list, i just did it in scratch files)

[13:27:02.0000] <Hixie>
shelleyp: (some of it became the examples in the spec)

[13:27:03.0000] <tantek>
shelleyp, it may be that the evaluation process for adding new features (e.g. microdata) is different than the evaluation process for dropping existing features, since existing features can be better evaluated based on observations in the wild.

[13:28:00.0000] <shelleyp>
Hixie: So an instance of implementation is a successful test of a given component of the HTML5?

[13:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: certainly the evaluation process for features for which we have a decade of experience can be far more rigorous

[13:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
shelleyp: it's a data point, of course. certainly not the only one. it is necessary but not sufficient.

[13:29:00.0000] <shelleyp>

[13:29:01.0000] <Hixie>

[13:29:02.0000] <Hixie>

[13:29:03.0000] <Hixie>
shelleyp: so i worked with the guy who runs that site to come up with something that would satisfy his need

[13:29:04.0000] <shelleyp>

[13:30:00.0000] <Hixie>

[06:39:01.0000] <Lachy>
s/the latter/the fomer/

[06:41:00.0000] <jgraham>

[06:42:00.0000] <Lachy>
jgraham, using details like that seems unintuitive

[06:42:01.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: Almost no one is going to do it anyway

[06:42:02.0000] <jgraham>
and for those people that do it doesn't seem that hard

[06:43:00.0000] <jgraham>
(since they will presumably have been trained/advocated into putting more information for AT users into their table)

[06:43:01.0000] <Lachy>
personally, I prefer just writing a summary in the prose before the table using an ordinary <p>. I fail to see why it needs to be directly associated with the table by markup

[06:44:00.0000] <Lachy>
I don't particularly like the idea of writing the summary in the caption, since captions are supposed to be short

[06:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
That's easy to solve - just stop supposing that captions should be short

[06:48:00.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: Captions, in general are not short. That is a weird HTMLism

[06:48:01.0000] <jgraham>
or rather HTML4ism

[06:49:00.0000] <zcorpan>
i put the summary in <p> in http://simon.html5.org/articles/mobile-results

[06:49:01.0000] <zcorpan>
maybe i should update it to put it in the caption

[06:49:02.0000] <Lachy>
they should be 1 or 2 sentences, just enough to describe the content of the figure/table 

[06:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
Why should they?

[06:56:01.0000] <beowulf>
Lachy: you suppose 1 or 2 sentences is enough to describe the content

[06:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
You could always make it two very long sentences with lots of semicolons

[06:57:01.0000] <Lachy>
because the content should be sufficiently self describing to not need an excessively long caption. Also, in most books and newspapers where I've seen captions, they're usually quite short

[07:07:00.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: Try writing a scientific paper with the major results in a table and fitting the caption into 1/2 sentences. It often isn't possible

[07:08:00.0000] <jgraham>
(I guess you could use <figure> for that case but it's not really clear why there should be two ways to do it with some arbitary cutoff based on length)

[07:09:00.0000] <Lachy>
jgraham, can you give an example of such a long caption?

[07:11:00.0000] <zcorpan>
Philip`: could you grep for pages that have non-whitespace and "-->" on the last non-whitespace line of scripts?

[07:12:00.0000] <zcorpan>
ie and opera have interesting behavior where the last line is stripped if it ends with -->

[07:13:00.0000] <zcorpan>
in opera the line doesn't get stripped if it also contains //

[07:13:01.0000] <Lachy>
which versions of IE have you tested?

[07:13:02.0000] <zcorpan>
Lachy: ie8

[07:13:03.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: Consider http://arxiv.org/pdf/astro-ph/0603449v2 Table 2 has a rather long caption. Many other tables do not. Insisting that they should be different elements doesn't make much sense

[07:13:04.0000] <zcorpan>
in ie it doesn't get stripped if the line contains // or <!-- (i think)

[07:13:05.0000] <Lachy>
ah, then maybe they're complaining about a syntax error if the the --> isn't commented out with //

[07:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
zcorpan: Do you mean something like "^\S+-->\s*</script>"?

[07:15:00.0000] <zcorpan>
Philip`: there could be whitespace on the line, just not only whitespace followed -->

[07:15:01.0000] <zcorpan>
foo = 'bar'; -->

[07:15:02.0000] <zcorpan>
</script>

[07:16:00.0000] <Lachy>

[07:16:01.0000] <Philip`>

[07:17:00.0000] <jgraham>

[07:17:01.0000] <Philip`>

[07:17:02.0000] <zcorpan>

[07:17:03.0000] <Lachy>

[07:19:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Lots of people write <script><!-- comment --></script>)

[07:22:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, I've seen that done in order to prevent some broken backend systems from mistakenly outputting empty scripts as <script src="..." />

[07:22:01.0000] <Lachy>
so they put in a comment to make it appear non-empty

[07:22:02.0000] <zcorpan>
Philip`: if they are overwhelming then yeah it would be good to remove those that have <!-- on the same line, too

[07:22:03.0000] <jgraham>
I think it is the cases where there is a --> but no <!-- or // that are the most interesting

[07:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me searches for (?i)^\s*(?!//|<!--)\S((?!//|<!--).)*-->\s*</script>

[07:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
(but only searching individual lines, so it won't find anything if the </script> is on the next line after the content)

[07:26:00.0000] <Lachy>
if you did the search using just (?i)^\s*(?!//|<!--)\S((?!//|<!--).)*-->\s* would you get too many false positives?

[07:27:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: If possible it would be nice to get cases where the </script> is on the next line too

[07:27:01.0000] <jgraham>
Although I guess that would be slower

[07:27:02.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: I expect that would find a bazillion HTML comments that have nothing to do with scripts

[07:28:00.0000] <Lachy>
oh, right, so you need a way to limit the search to within script elements

[14:16:00.0000] <webben>
(OT): http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/syndata.html#charset Anybody know what CSS2.1 means by "byte" here?

[14:17:00.0000] <webben>
I'm trying to implement CSS2.1 character encoding sniffing, and I'm just looking at the character encodings that involve transcoding.

[14:17:01.0000] <webben>
Starting with GSM 03.38.

[14:17:02.0000] <gsnedders>
/me notes this would be easier if he hadn't just crashed his web browser

[14:19:00.0000] <webben>
What's confusing me is that whereas you can grab octets for (say) UTF-8 bytes (i.e. octets) and match against their regexes, GSM 03.38 takes packs 7-bit codepoints into octets.

[14:19:01.0000] <webben>
so if you just naively grab the octets, they won't match that regex

[14:19:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Well, if it is codepoints then doesn't that give you the Unicode string?

[14:19:03.0000] <webben>
you actually have to decompose them to septets.

[14:20:00.0000] <webben>
gsnedders: I'm using codepoints loosely. These aren't unicode codepoints.

[14:20:01.0000] <gsnedders>
/me thinks this would be easier to answer if he actually knew what GSM did :)

[14:21:00.0000] <webben>
There the abstract hex values in the GSM 03.38 character encoding, which can be represented into 7 bits, which are then packed into octets such that one octet contains bits from multiple codepoints.

[14:21:01.0000] <webben>
http://pda.etsi.org/exchangefolder/ts_100900v070200p.pdf is the GSM 03.38 spec.

[14:22:00.0000] <webben>
and http://www.dreamfabric.com/sms/ is a English-language description of what it does.

[14:22:01.0000] <webben>
I've been wrestingly with this in increasing confusion all day; figured there's quite a lot of spec-compliance and character encoding knowledge in this channel ;)

[14:23:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me would ignore that table in CSS21 :)

[14:23:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Other things make more sense for GSM 03.38, IMO.

[14:23:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Or maybe I'm wrong

[14:23:03.0000] <gsnedders>
/me shrugs

[14:23:04.0000] <gsnedders>
Don't ask me!

[14:23:05.0000] <webben>
I've also been wondering: who delivers CSS in GSM 03.38? I can't find any reference to this anywhere else.

[14:24:00.0000] <webben>
/me is also amused that i18n's test cases for CSS and charset don't actually cover all these random encodings.

[14:24:01.0000] <webben>
(http://www.w3.org/International/tests/list-html-css#charset)

what does it say about the success of an accessibility feature that the leading screen reader has code to suppress it?

[08:31:00.0000] <jgraham>
(there was a machine-learning based paper that claimed something like 95% although I can't remember quite what that referred to)

[08:32:00.0000] <jgraham>
(clearly it can't be "right in 95% of all cases because you cn do rather better than that just by saying all tables are layout tables)

[08:33:00.0000] <jgraham>
s/s/s"/

[08:33:01.0000] <hsivonen>
anyway, I can buy the argument that summary should be 'in', because .gov sites may manage to use it right and that abuse by others is suppressed by algorithms

[08:34:00.0000] <hsivonen>
but then why does the .gov guide recommend <caption>

[08:34:01.0000] <hsivonen>
and can we have @summary for .gov without having all these other people write summaries only to be suppressed?

[08:36:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I wonder what kind of effect would a validator that whined about non-empty summary on tables that JAWS would consider layout tables would have

[08:36:01.0000] <hsivonen>
minus one 'would'

[08:38:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: It is worth noting that the data was not so conclusive about .gov managing to use @summary right

[08:38:01.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: that, too

[08:39:00.0000] <jgraham>
I don't think we should be keeping heavily abused features just because some small subset of people might get them right sometimes and the bad effects of people getting them wrong can be mitigated by significant client side effort

[08:40:00.0000] <jgraham>
Not least because it makes developing clients significantly harder; to compete with JAWS you have to reverse engineer its table heuristics

[08:40:01.0000] <jgraham>
or build better ones

[08:40:02.0000] <jgraham>
or offer a worse user experience

[08:40:03.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: unless HTML5 saves prospective developers the cost by having a canned explanation of what JAWS does

[08:41:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: Since FS have no interest in giving that to us we would have to reverse engineer it. But that sort of thing should not be codified in the spec

[08:41:01.0000] <jgraham>
It would be an intersting and useful excersie though

[08:42:00.0000] <jgraham>
although if they have used e.g. machine learning the algorithm could be rather complex to pin down

[08:42:01.0000] <Dashiva>
"Structure is nothing if it is all you got. Skeletons spook people if they try to walk around on their own. I really wonder why XML does not."

[08:54:00.0000] <webben>
jgraham: "should not be codified in the spec" ... why not?

[08:54:01.0000] <webben>
Seems like an important area of interoperable consumption of the web corpus.

[09:02:00.0000] <jgraham>
webben: Because it seems like a UI issue

[09:02:01.0000] <jgraham>
(sort of)

[09:05:00.0000] <jgraham>
and because making a dejure method of categorising tables into layout and non-layout unnecessarily freezes the state of the art

[09:05:01.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: I disagree. I think it's a semantic issue for answering "what's the summary if any of this table"

[09:07:00.0000] <webben>
jgraham: I don't think it's a UI issue. If one wants to allow conforming UAs to implement even better algorithms, it could always be a suggested algorithm.

[09:08:00.0000] <webben>
that lowers the bar to creating a UA, while still allowing evolution of better heuristics.

[09:15:00.0000] <jgraham>
I am not opposed to an informative algorithm, perhaps in a seperate document. I would be very worried about defining semantic issues based on things that have a certian known failure rate and no manual override

[12:38:03.0000] <ezyang>
3986 supercedes 2396 

[12:39:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[12:39:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(I mean what the XML namespaces spec means by "URI", I don't care about what RFC obsoletes what :P)

[12:39:02.0000] <ezyang>
jaja 

[12:40:00.0000] <gsnedders>
(I mean, if I wanted to throw fatal errors on invalid namespace names, then it'd be better that it's behaviour was constant and didn't depend on what RFC I chose to implement, as there should hopefully be a static reference in the spec.)

[12:41:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Oh, more fun: xml-names first ed. references RFC 2396 and second edition RFC 3986

[12:41:01.0000] <gsnedders>
/me wonders which to be compatible with

[12:41:02.0000] <ezyang>
That makes sense 

[12:41:03.0000] <ezyang>
3986 is mostly a strict superset of 2396, so you should use that 

[12:41:04.0000] <gsnedders>
The problem is it means a document using namespaces may throw parse errors if it implements the first edition.

[12:42:00.0000] <ezyang>
Unlikely. 

[12:42:01.0000] <gsnedders>
But possible. Bear in mind the big issue of XML 1.0 Fifth edition.

[12:43:00.0000] <gsnedders>
(i.e., a document valid under that can be not even well-formed according to another XML 1.0 processor, because it implements an earlier edition)

[12:43:01.0000] <gsnedders>
/me wonders how to implement URI validation

[12:43:02.0000] <ezyang>
I'm pretty sure they only sanity check URIs, and don't do an in-depth check. 

[12:44:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Processors normally do not checking :)

[12:44:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[12:44:02.0000] <ezyang>
btw, you should read "D.2.  Modifications"

[04:53:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[04:55:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[04:57:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[04:57:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[17:05:00.0000] <hober>
well, think of it in terms of postel's law. a UA is at the 'liberal in what you accept' end, matching your "don't mess" behavior.

[17:05:01.0000] <hober>
an editor / authoring tool is at the 'conservative in what you send' end

[17:06:00.0000] <hober>
hence authoring requirements being stricter than UA requirements

[17:16:00.0000] <sayrer>
hober, I am saying that those requirements are incompatibl

[17:16:01.0000] <sayrer>
e

[17:17:00.0000] <hober>

[17:20:00.0000] <roc>

[17:20:01.0000] <roc>
which is what most people want from an editor

[17:23:00.0000] <hober>
hmm. conformant documents round-trip with conformant tools. non-conformant documents round-trip if your tools are also non-conformant.

[04:38:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Well, yeah. Any example to something regulated by business and law is somewhat irrelevant by default when it comes to a volunteer and amateur web

[04:39:00.0000] <jgraham>
My assumption is that she believes that an "empiracist" would regard disabled parking spots as a failure if it could be shown that they were more often used by non-disabled people than by disabled people

[04:39:01.0000] <jgraham>
It might be true that they are used in that way. But that doesn't make them a failure

[04:40:00.0000] <jgraham>
Because they might nevertheless increase the accessibility of shops to disabled people by increasing the chance that they will get a spot near the shops

[04:41:00.0000] <jgraham>
Thus allowing them to go shoppiing when they would otherwise not be able to

[04:42:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I've been avoid calling it an analogy because it's a very bad one :)

[04:42:01.0000] <jgraham>
On the other hand they would be a failure if they were less cost effective at achieving this goal than some other solution that could be used instead. 

[04:42:02.0000] <jgraham>
And were preventing that alternative solution being deployed

[04:43:00.0000] <Dashiva>
You also have to look at the overall result. Non-disabled use of disabled parking still produces utility.

[04:44:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Whereas an ignored attribute is pure author waste

[04:44:01.0000] <jgraham>
True

[04:46:00.0000] <jgraham>
(as an example of an alternative solution, we can imagine requiring businesses to ferry disabled users directly to the door from any parking space. This would have greater benefits (door to door service) but also much greater costs)

[05:19:00.0000] <annevk42>
I have the feeling some of the ECMAScript folks have been working on "obsoleting" the origin security infrastructure whereas we are working on strengthening it

[05:20:00.0000] <annevk42>
E.g. they are working on safe subsets of ECMAScript that can run within the same origin somehow for ads etc. whereas we have the sandboxed <iframe> feature to give those ads a distinct origin

[06:00:00.0000] <annevk42>
(My main worry though is that I am bringing this up and nobody else.)

[06:02:00.0000] <jgraham>
annevk42: I agree ith you but I don't kno if it is a problem

[06:04:00.0000] <annevk42>
jgraham, maybe it's just a problem for me then

[06:04:01.0000] <jgraham>
annevk42: Why is it a problem to have two possible approaches to the same problem, in this case?

[06:04:02.0000] <annevk42>
jgraham, some of the ECMAScript folks are asking for specific XMLHttpRequest changes that do not seem to take into account the feature set that sandboxed <iframe>s offer

[06:05:00.0000] <jgraham>
Oh

[06:05:01.0000] <jgraham>
Well I guess it depends on the merits of those changes

[06:05:02.0000] <annevk42>
jgraham, one security researcher makes claims about CORS based on the assumption that the Web will go in the direction of Caja/etc.

[06:06:00.0000] <annevk42>
jgraham, the merits heavily depend on where we end up, security wise

[06:06:01.0000] <jgraham>
I think it is bad to assume that either technique will dominate

[06:07:00.0000] <annevk42>
you also think it is bad to have several ways to do the same thing

[06:08:00.0000] <annevk42>
and given the API bloat that XMLHttpRequest already has I'm not inclined to sprinkle around some more

[06:09:00.0000] <jgraham>
In general I agree but with something like security there is more of an argument for more than one way to do it

[06:09:01.0000] <jgraham>
Assuming the ways are complementary and don't crowd each other out of the market

[06:10:00.0000] <jgraham>
(with different browsers implementing different solutions)

[06:11:00.0000] <jgraham>
Or cause undue confusion about the right approach to use

[06:12:00.0000] <annevk42>
I think you need one approach as it affects how ad platforms have to work, how you have to do communication securely, whether origins can be trusted, etc.

[06:13:00.0000] <jgraham>
I don't think we will (in general) want to assume different origins can be trusted any time soon

[06:13:01.0000] <annevk42>
it's about whether you can trust your own

[06:13:02.0000] <jgraham>
ad platforms should just pick whichever solution meets their needs best

[06:15:00.0000] <jgraham>

[08:39:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, classid and type do have different semantics though (what piece of code is preferred to run this thing, what is the data type of this thing), that have been shown to have utility in various systems, even before the web.

[08:39:01.0000] <tantek>
E.g. MacOS files have the notion of Type and Creator. If the Creator is found for opening a file then it is used, otherwise, the system looks for what other applications support the Type of document, and give the user the option of opening the document in one of those apps.

[08:40:00.0000] <tantek>
And you could certainly base support for classid on existing web content that uses it.

[08:41:00.0000] <tantek>
/me is not a huge supporter of classid, but there are the facts behind it that should be considered from a scientific perspective before rejecting/removing it.

[08:47:00.0000] <gsnedders>
In title case, should à be capitalized (en français)?

[15:25:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[15:25:01.0000] <Lachy>

[15:26:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:26:03.0000] <gsnedders>

[15:26:04.0000] <Hixie>

[15:27:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:27:01.0000] <Lachy>

[15:27:05.0000] <jgraham>

[15:27:06.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: "percentage" makes no sense as one word because "per cent" is two

[15:28:00.0000] <jgraham>
It isn't going to work

[15:29:00.0000] <Lachy>
it also makes no sense because the word cent on its own has its own meaning as a unit of currency, and when you write it as per cent it makes it appear as though it's referring to the currency, not %

[15:29:01.0000] <jgraham>
Fun fact: There is research into double negatives that shows that languages go in cycles on whether double negatives are used for negation or not

[15:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: You think words should only ever have one meaning?

[15:30:01.0000] <Lachy>
no, I didn't say that

[15:30:02.0000] <jgraham>
So a language will start with single negation and people will start using double negaion for emphasis. Then people will again start to favour single negation for brevity and the cycle will repeat

[15:30:03.0000] <jgraham>
Or something

[15:31:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Lachy: cent also means one hundred :P

[15:31:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(At least in Latin, and Latin is a proper language)

[15:31:02.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, consider the phrase "I got 5 per cent".  Depending on context, that could mean "I got 5 [items] per cent (currency)" or "I got 5%"

[15:32:00.0000] <Lachy>
writing it without the space removes the ambiguity and makes it easier to read

[15:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
("per cent" is apparently an abbreviation of "per centum", so the two-word form seems the more original)

[15:34:00.0000] <jgraham>
gsnedders: The phrase "proper language" used without a smilie is sure to raise ire

[15:34:01.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: Trying to make all sentences unambiguous independent of context seems like a battle that was lost millennia ago

[15:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
Context matters, and this isn't an example that seems ambiguous when you do have context

[15:36:00.0000] <jgraham>
I would wager that thre has never been a language that could be understood in an entirely context free way

[15:36:01.0000] <jgraham>
Because the difficulty of arriving at such a thing would be huge yet its value would be rather small

[15:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
Not even Lojban

[15:43:00.0000] <jgraham>
I guess languages with no (native) speakers don't count. But even so I wonder if it is truly context free

[13:55:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:55:01.0000] <Hixie>

[13:55:02.0000] <Hixie>

[13:55:07.0000] <annevk42>

[13:56:02.0000] <jgraham>

[13:56:03.0000] <annevk42>

[14:17:00.0000] <jacobolus>
archtech: why wouldn't it be?

[14:19:00.0000] <archtech>
jacobolus, the line break defines two implicit line elements, say I have this:   Hello, this is <b>some bold text,<br>and we continue on a new line.</b> Done.

[14:19:01.0000] <archtech>
Now those are two lines

[14:19:02.0000] <archtech>
<line>Hello, this is <b>some bold text,</line><line>and we continue on a new line.</b> Done.</line>

[14:19:03.0000] <archtech>
There's no valid way to nest this.

[14:20:00.0000] <jacobolus>
the same could be said about the '.' character creating two implicit 'sentence' elements

[14:20:01.0000] <jacobolus>
etc.

[14:20:02.0000] <archtech>
My point is that a break is a metacharacter.

[14:21:00.0000] <archtech>
The actual objects are lines, are they not?

[14:21:01.0000] <jacobolus>
I don't think so, no

[14:21:02.0000] <archtech>

[16:02:00.0000] <arun_>
I have a rough editor's draft of the File API spec, which I'd welcome discussion on.  There are a few issues with it still (Callbacks *and* ErrorCallbacks have to be handled; editorial nits; sample code nits) but I'd love to get feedback from the channel: http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/FileUpload/publish/FileAPI.xhtml

[16:03:00.0000] <annevk42>

[16:03:01.0000] <arun_>

[16:03:03.0000] <annevk42>

[16:04:00.0000] <arun_>
In particular, I'd like to hear about FileDialog.  I think it's a good idea, but I've had nits to the effect that honing <input type="file" ... > behavior is better.

[16:05:00.0000] <annevk42>
"This interface describes a single file in a FileList," I think something else for this would work better since we might not always want to have them in lists

[16:05:01.0000] <sicking>

[16:05:02.0000] <Hixie>
to repeat the comments i made privately: you'll want to make better use of rfc2119, and i recommend splitting File into two, FileData with everything but the name, and File with the name, where File inherits from FileData

[16:05:03.0000] <sicking>
it also assumes that lists come from the FileDialog

[16:06:00.0000] <annevk42>

[16:06:01.0000] <sicking>

[16:07:00.0000] <sicking>

[16:08:00.0000] <Hixie>

[16:08:01.0000] <arun_>

[16:08:02.0000] <annevk42>

[16:08:03.0000] <Hixie>
i agree that whatever File inherits from shouldn't have a type

[16:08:04.0000] <sicking>

[16:09:00.0000] <sicking>

[16:09:01.0000] <Hixie>

[16:09:02.0000] <Hixie>
arun_: similarly binary data coming from a WebSocket would be a FileData (or Binary or Blob or whatever you prefer), not a File

[16:09:03.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, oh, no, they don't

[16:09:04.0000] <annevk42>
spawning file picker dialogs to users seems open to abuse and we already have somewhat sandboxed way for picking files we can reuse

[16:09:05.0000] <arun_>
OK; you also suggested that obliging developers to handle both the data callback and the error callback was a stylistic choice.  No strong opinions either way?

[16:10:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, ah, now i remember, we figured it was mostly useful for piecing together a data: uri, but since we expose a data: uri we didn't feel that mimetype was that important

[16:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
arun: that's just an api design decision, no right answer really. personally i design callback-style apis such that they call either the success or the failure callbacks, never both, but it depends on the way you'd expect them to be used.

[16:11:01.0000] <annevk42>
while we brainstorm, it would be sort of nice to just like with XMLHttpRequest you can get a Document out of it and maybe even HTMLImageElement / ImageData / JSON

[16:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
getting an HTMLImageElement would be nice, but long term what would be even nicer is being able to get a short (not data:) URL out of it

[16:12:01.0000] <arun_>
annevk42, I agree it is open to abuse.  I had an ednote about conditions where implementations would want to define when to raise a FileError with a SECURITY_ERR, and FileDialog abuse seemed like a prime choice.

[16:12:02.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, since it's an async API, the UA can show a unintrusive warning if it suspects misuse. A'la GeoLocation

[16:12:03.0000] <annevk42>
sicking, but why have two ways to do things?

[16:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. .getAsUrl() and it returns "magic-file-or-whatever://origin.example.com/0" where that URL works only for browsing contexts in the same origin

[16:13:01.0000] <arun_>
Basically, major web applications like Flickr and GMail use the Flash uploader.  Sure, we could address some of this by changing how user agents handle input type="file", but a programmatic FileDialog seemed useful.

[16:13:02.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, because a lot of sites are working around the uglyness of the current <input type=file>

[16:13:03.0000] <Hixie>
that would let us automatically take a FileData object and plug it into anything like <video> or <img> or whatever

[16:13:04.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, gmail being an obvious example

[16:13:05.0000] <annevk42>
I'd argue we should solve that with CSS, not ECMAScript

[16:14:00.0000] <annevk42>
the reason Gmail/Flickr use Flash for uploading is mostly multiple files (<input type=file multiple>) and I suppose async upload (using XMLHttpRequest)

[16:14:01.0000] <arun_>
annevk42, it's not just ugliness, it's also functionality, but HTML5 does allow input type="file" to have multiple selects, etc.  I'm in two minds about this.

[16:14:02.0000] <sicking>

[16:14:03.0000] <annevk42>

[16:18:10.0000] <Hixie>

[16:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
but i think it's a better solution long term than getting HTMLImageElements out of FileData objects

[16:19:01.0000] <sicking>
yeah

[16:19:02.0000] <sicking>
i think we can stick to data-uris for now

[16:19:03.0000] <arun_>
OK, this is good stuff.  I'll leave FileDialog in for now, but clean up File a bit more, maybe break it into two (File, FileData or something)

[16:19:04.0000] <sicking>
otherwise we'll have to define things like what File.magicalHTMLImageProducer().src returns and such

[16:20:00.0000] <annevk42>
i'm still opposed to FileDialog fwiw

[16:20:01.0000] <annevk42>
I'd rather wait and see if <input type=file multiple> + XHR can do the trick

[16:20:02.0000] <arun_>
annevk42, so's Hixie.  But I'm unmoved for now ;-)

[16:20:03.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, XHR??

[16:20:04.0000] <Hixie>
i'm not a fan of FileDialog either, i think leaving the security to the last minute is a bad way of doing things

[16:20:05.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, you mean CSS?

[16:20:06.0000] <Hixie>
i don't mind something new, but security needs to be first and foremost in mind

[16:21:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, how is it different from geolocation?

[16:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
such that the entire design precludes abuse

[16:21:02.0000] <annevk42>
sicking, people articulated the desire for async upload / fragment upload

[16:21:03.0000] <arun_>
Hixie, I'm not sure we're quite leaving it to the last minute; we're discussing it out of the starter gate :)

[16:21:04.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: geolocation doesn't pop up a modal dialog

[16:21:05.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, neither would this need to

[16:21:06.0000] <arun_>
Hixie, even here, we're NOT suggesting a modal dialog

[16:21:07.0000] <arun_>
Hixie, in fact I mention a non-modal one

[16:21:08.0000] <Hixie>
arun_: what i mean is that you have the API designed before the security solution

[16:21:09.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, no, we talked about this a lot

[16:22:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, not sure if all possible implementation strategies ended up in the draft, but we have several in mind

[16:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
arun_: what flash does is a modal dialog. If it's supposed to be something else, then that's better, but the spec needs to make that crystal clear, not just leave it up to hte UA.

[16:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
arun_: and if it's not what flash does, then it's not clear it addresses the same use case :-)

[16:23:00.0000] <arun_>
Hixie, ahh, there are two things here.  1. The actual File Picker and 2. The user interaction for permission.  But yeah, that must be made clearer.

[16:23:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, what I want to do is to leave it up to the UA to decide what to do, but give a few non-normative possible strategies that the implementation can use

[16:24:00.0000] <annevk42>
modal or non-modal it's a new API for authors, new UI for users (sounds more complex already) and more complexity for implementors

[16:24:01.0000] <annevk42>
for something that's already possible

[16:25:00.0000] <arun_>
annevk42, good points -- I think really explaining the use case will get us on the way to resolution.  

[16:25:01.0000] <annevk42>
the main use case I'm hearing is styling

[16:25:02.0000] <annevk42>
i'm not at all convinced that's a good reason

[16:26:00.0000] <annevk42>
there's been no attempt whatsoever by any browser at letting authors style the file input control

[16:26:01.0000] <arun_>
annevk42, we could say that the *existing* input type ="file" mechanism in browsers today is ugly and causes developers of big web apps to use Flash.  FileDialog is one solution, and doesn't need to be bound to using an element in your application.

[16:26:02.0000] <annevk42>
people use Flash because they can allow users to pick multiple files

[16:26:03.0000] <annevk42>
that's far more a reason than styling

[16:26:04.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, It's a complaint I hear a lot, that people think that <input type=file> is ugly and wanting to use something else.

[16:26:05.0000] <arun_>
But multiple selections (as spec'd in HTML5) is a big reason.

[16:27:00.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, i don't think it's the whole truth that people use flash just for multiple

[16:27:01.0000] <arun_>
annevk42, yes -- multiple selection is a big one, and if that's the prime use case, I agree that it can be solved within input type = "file" ... but I'm not sure it is 

[16:28:00.0000] <annevk42>
sicking, yes, but address the styling problem where it should be addressed

[16:28:01.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, first of all I think that many people aren't able to select multiple files in a filepicker anyway (requires keyboard shortcuts on windows)

[16:28:02.0000] <annevk42>
arun_, my suggestion is to first fix multiple selections and async upload for files and then see if it's good enough

[16:28:03.0000] <annevk42>
sicking, no, you can just drag around with your mouse iirc

[16:29:00.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, ah, yeah, if files have neighboring names

[16:29:01.0000] <annevk42>
for photo sites that seems likely

[16:29:02.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, true

[16:30:00.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, for gmail, not so sure

[16:30:01.0000] <annevk42>
depends on what people attach primarily

[16:30:02.0000] <annevk42>
hixie would be in a better place to answer that one I guess :)

[16:30:03.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, and again, i'm not convinced people generally know about that

[16:30:04.0000] <sicking>
annevk42, we can of course ask google :)

[16:31:00.0000] <annevk42>
but you're talking about users, i was suggesting why web developers want it

[16:31:01.0000] <sicking>
i mean we can ask google why they use flash

[16:31:02.0000] <sicking>
i.e. what made them not consider HTML good enough

[16:31:03.0000] <annevk42>
when i log in to gmail it doesn't use flash

[16:34:00.0000] <Lachy>

[16:34:01.0000] <annevk42>

[16:34:02.0000] <annevk42>

[16:35:00.0000] <sicking>

[12:52:00.0000] <Hixie>

[12:53:00.0000] <Hixie>

[07:05:00.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: The actual parsing of entities we can't really change (because of need for compat. with existing content), what we can change is what is conforming, and making & legal on its own gets fairly complex.

[07:05:01.0000] <archtech>
gsnedders, the format of entities is that above today

[07:06:00.0000] <annevk42>
e.g. &copy= does turn into ©=

[07:06:01.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: It isn't. Things like &copy do parse like that, and need to for compatibility, even though they are non-conforming.

[07:07:00.0000] <archtech>
gsnedders, not every non-conforming change should be supported

[07:07:01.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: Browser vendors will not make changes to parsing that breaks existing content.

[07:08:00.0000] <gsnedders>
(And that is absolutely non-negotiable: if the spec changes to something incompatible, we'll just break the spec)

[07:08:01.0000] <archtech>
gsnedders, does that mean <b> foo <i> bar </i> baz </b> is part of HTML5

[07:08:02.0000] <archtech>
ops

[07:08:03.0000] <archtech>
I mean b i b i

[07:08:04.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: It has a defined parse tree. It is non-conforming.

[07:08:05.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: Any character stream has a defined parse tree.

[07:09:00.0000] <archtech>
So is that valid HTML5?

[07:09:01.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: No, it is non-conforming.

[07:09:02.0000] <archtech>
gsnedders, but &copy= is?

[07:09:03.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: No, that is non-conforming too.

[07:09:04.0000] <archtech>
I see.

[07:10:00.0000] <archtech>
So HTML5 defines the exact behavior of non-conforming code.

[07:10:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Yes.

[07:10:02.0000] <archtech>
And & as a literal is supported, but non-conforming.

[07:10:03.0000] <archtech>
For example: M & M

[07:11:00.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: That is legal because a whitespace character follows it

[07:12:00.0000] <archtech>
I see.

[07:12:01.0000] <archtech>
Thanks for the info, guys

[07:13:00.0000] <gsnedders>
archtech: The only place you're allowed a & followed by anything within script and style

[07:17:00.0000] <archtech>
gsnedders, sure

[07:17:01.0000] <archtech>
those are defined as literal blocks terminated by strictly </script> and </style> I suppose

[07:17:02.0000] <archtech>
this is their de-facto behavior.

[07:17:03.0000] <gsnedders>
Yeah

[07:17:04.0000] <archtech>
nice

[07:17:05.0000] <gsnedders>
(case insensitively)

[07:17:06.0000] <archtech>
oh yea

[07:20:00.0000] <archtech>
I gotta check how html5 deals with textarea

[07:20:01.0000] <archtech>
;)

[07:20:02.0000] <archtech>
entities are supported.. but nothing else :)

[07:21:00.0000] <archtech>
curious one

[07:21:01.0000] <gsnedders>
/me is kinda running around, but can probably answer most of these questions :)

[08:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
archtech: Actually they're terminated by "</script" and "</style" (case-insensitively) followed by whitespace or "/" or ">" or EOF

[08:53:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: Not EOF, I thought, after the latest change.

[08:54:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: Well, I guess the contents to remain, we just drop the end tag

[08:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders: I'm just going by what http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/syntax.html#close-tag-open-state says, for look-ahead recognition of the end tag

[08:58:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: You're right.

[08:58:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: Ignore me, I'm ignorant.

[05:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
why is it that all studies I've ever seen comparing video and audio codecs always rely on subjective analysis by a person to rate the quality? Surely, there are algorithms available that could be implemented in a program to objectively compare the original lossless video with the compressed versions

[05:26:00.0000] <Lachy>
and then whichever compressed version is closest to the original is superior

[05:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's easy to make quantitative comparisons (like PSNR), but very hard to make ones that closely correspond to what a human would subjectively perceive as quality

[05:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
e.g. a human would care much more about blurriness in the compression of human faces than of background details

[05:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
and a human might prefer an image that looks sharp than one that's more faithful to the original

[05:49:00.0000] <jgraham>

[05:50:00.0000] <jgraham>

[05:51:00.0000] <jgraham>
*mother

[05:53:00.0000] <Philip`>
It wouldn't make presentational markup conforming - it would just mean the answer to "is this page conforming?" would always be "mu", as far as I can tell

[05:55:00.0000] <Philip`>
(You could still ask a question like "does this page follow the Best Practices described in this other document that isn't the HTML5 specification?")

[05:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
(and there could be competition between different groups trying to define the most useful sets of best practices for authors, rather than codifying one set in the spec itself)

[05:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
Anyway, it certainly would reduce rathole discussions, because they would all be consumed by a single giant Sarlacc-hole

[01:53:00.0000] <jgraham>
What happens if I have some HTML like <body bgcolor="black"><article><font color="white">... and the <article> contents ends up in a feed? ill it be unreadable? Taking some but not all style information seems like it could be dangerous

[01:53:01.0000] <jgraham>
s/ill/will/

[01:55:00.0000] <Dashiva>
jgraham: Well, that's "wrong" to begin with

[01:55:01.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: In what way?

[01:55:02.0000] <jgraham>
Under the assumption that anything that works in a UA is conforming

[01:55:03.0000] <Dashiva>
You should set text color on the body element as well

[01:56:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Always specify foreground and background together

[01:56:01.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: According to whom? Not according to the supposed no-author-requirements HTML spec

[01:57:00.0000] <Dashiva>
According to the best practices that are supposed to replace them

[01:57:01.0000] <Dashiva>
No requirements includes the freedom to shoot yourself in the foot

[01:58:00.0000] <jgraham>
Yeah but I'm trying to work out why that's a good thing

[01:58:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Has anyone claimed that?

[01:59:00.0000] <jgraham>
That having no author requirements is a good thing? Sure

[01:59:01.0000] <Dashiva>
That's a choice between evils, not goods

[01:59:02.0000] <jgraham>
Can you explain more?

[01:59:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Requirements come with ratholes, bikesheds, and aren't enforced

[02:00:00.0000] <Dashiva>
The argument (as I read it) goes that avoiding all those weighs up for the loss of the guideance authority that could be provided

[02:00:01.0000] <jgraham>
Lack of requirments will come with a huge rathole, at the bottom of which will be the original ratholes but renamed "best practices"

[02:01:00.0000] <jgraham>
So I don't see any possibility for gain here

[02:01:01.0000] <Dashiva>
That is the gain

[02:01:02.0000] <Dashiva>
That huge rathole will always be there, that's what good authoring is all about

[02:01:03.0000] <Dashiva>
But without requirements, we outsource the war over where the hole should be

[02:02:00.0000] <jgraham>
As far as I can tell the main agenda here is that some people don't like the HTML5 draft because it doesn't endorse something that they hold dear to them. So they have decided that the only way out is to try to remove all restrictions and be told "do what you like"

[02:02:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Well, the basic complaint holds: What use are requirements that no one actually requires?

[02:03:00.0000] <jgraham>
Sometimes this is wrapped up in theoretical RFC 2119 arguments

[02:04:00.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: The point of authoring requirements in a language with error correcting clients is not to describe the only possible way of doing things

[02:04:01.0000] <jgraham>
It is to reduce the authoring surface of the language so that it does not grow without bounds and so there are as  few sharp edges as possible

[02:05:00.0000] <Dashiva>
But nobody reads those requirements

[02:05:01.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: Demonstrably untrue

[02:05:02.0000] <Dashiva>
They read second- or third-hand references that also includes local author intent, best practices, misconceptions, urban legends, etc etc

[02:06:00.0000] <jgraham>
There has been a huge movement toward following standards. Yes there is a lot of cargo cult nonsense. But there is enough essentially good stuff that we should no thro the whole thing away just to make the lives of spec authors better

[02:06:01.0000] <jgraham>
We even have a design principle about that

[02:06:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Nobody's saying we should throw it away

[02:06:03.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: They really are

[02:07:00.0000] <Dashiva>
They may think so

[02:07:01.0000] <Dashiva>
But those references people use will still exist

[02:07:02.0000] <Dashiva>
It's only mark's assholes that will be weakened

[02:09:00.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: I would expect one effect of removing conformance requirements to be that people will start to reject HTML5 for cargo-cult reasons

[02:09:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Oh, sure. But there wouldn't be anything for them to reject. It would be a user agent spec full and whole.

[02:09:02.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: Not really.

[02:10:00.0000] <jgraham>
It still will define a language

[02:10:01.0000] <jgraham>

[02:10:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Now we're back at html4 ground

[02:10:03.0000] <jgraham>
?

[02:10:04.0000] <Dashiva>
The language in the spec does not matter for authors, authors and users only go via user agents

[02:11:00.0000] <jgraham>
But we just discussed this. Authors learn from somewhere and that somewhere often has looked at the spec

[02:11:01.0000] <jgraham>
And authors do use vaidators

[02:12:00.0000] <jgraham>
and validators have read the spec for sure

[02:12:01.0000] <Dashiva>
But again the authors don't go directly to the spec

[02:12:02.0000] <Dashiva>
They see the validator's rules, which would include all kinds of best practices

[02:13:00.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: What kind of best practices are encoded by validator.w3.org or validator.nu, beyond what is in the spec?

[02:13:01.0000] <Dashiva>
All the author requirements

[02:14:00.0000] <jgraham>
I mean today

[02:14:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Today there isn't much need, henri gets it put into the spec instead

[02:14:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[02:15:00.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: The concept of downplayed errors is silly

[02:15:01.0000] <jgraham>
That is a UI issue

[02:15:02.0000] <Dashiva>
If so, that strenghtens the point

[02:16:00.0000] <Dashiva>
These are things he doesn't want the validator to mark as errors. Now he's working inside the spec, if the spec dropped author reqs he would just go ahead and do it directly

[02:16:01.0000] <Philip`>
What if someone else writing a different validator has different ideas of what should be considered an error or a warning?

[02:17:00.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: So in the future what do you envison? validator.w3.org uses best practices document A. commercial.validator.org uses weaker best practices document B to iucrease marketshare. Validator validate.net is written by areholes and has a whole load of additional requirements. An author tries to validate her document. What does she conclude?

[02:17:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Then you get competition in who validates the best

[02:17:02.0000] <Philip`>
Putting those requirements in the spec prevents the benefits of competition, because there will only be one official blessed notion of validity

[02:17:03.0000] <Philip`>
which seems similar to the argument against putting machine-readable schemas in the spec

[02:17:04.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: Re: dowwnplayed errors, Henri can already choose to downplay any error he likes. It is a pure UI issue

[02:18:00.0000] <Dashiva>
jgraham: Again, sure. It's not material to my point. The point is that he puts effort into convincing Hixie to mark them as downplayed. That means he cares. 

[02:19:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: The problem with putting schemas in the spec is that it is not possible to express all conformance requirements in schema and there is the possibility of divergence between the actual requirements and the schema (due either to the limitations or to bugs)

[02:20:00.0000] <Dashiva>
This situation exists even now, of course

[02:20:01.0000] <Dashiva>
There are requirements outside the HTML5 spec

[02:20:02.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: And I still maintain it is silly to have the requirements in the spec. So I don't see that I'm taking an inconsistent position

[02:20:03.0000] <Dashiva>
This whole thing would just be moving one set of requirements into some other (possible more than one) location

[02:21:00.0000] <jgraham>
s/requirements/downplayed errors/

[02:21:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[02:22:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[02:22:01.0000] <jgraham>

[02:22:03.0000] <jgraham>
"

[02:23:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[02:24:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[02:24:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[02:26:00.0000] <jgraham>

[02:27:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[06:14:01.0000] <jgraham>

[06:14:02.0000] <jgraham>

[06:15:00.0000] <annevk42>

[06:15:01.0000] <jgraham>
Specifically the difference beteen <font> and <span style> is that authors using <span> must be aware of CSS and have taken a concious decision to use inline style in place of seperated style

[06:15:02.0000] <jgraham>
That seems like a positive ting

[06:16:00.0000] <jgraham>
If a tool emits <span style> in place of <font> it is neutral

[06:16:01.0000] <jgraham>
So therefore removing <font> seems to have an overall positive balance

[06:17:00.0000] <hsivonen>
somehow I'm more annoyed when OpenOffice.org or Nvu emit style=''

[06:17:01.0000] <jgraham>

[06:17:02.0000] <jgraham>
*aesthetic

[06:18:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:18:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:18:02.0000] <jgraham>

[06:18:03.0000] <Philip`>

[06:19:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:19:01.0000] <jgraham>

[06:19:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:20:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:20:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:21:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:21:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:22:00.0000] <jgraham>

[06:22:01.0000] <jgraham>

[06:23:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:23:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:24:00.0000] <hsivonen>
if the user selects two words and picks red, not generating <font color> is quite silly

[06:24:01.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: Why is rendering some text invisible dangerous?

[06:25:00.0000] <Philip`>

[06:25:01.0000] <jgraham>

[06:25:02.0000] <Philip`>

[06:25:04.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:26:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:26:01.0000] <jgraham>

[06:27:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:27:01.0000] <jgraham>

[06:28:00.0000] <Philip`>

[06:28:01.0000] <hsivonen>
<font color> survives syndication and legacy tools better

[06:28:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: indeed. much better example.

[06:30:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me is being slow and doesn't understand why that is a bette example

[06:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: Because it's conceptually very similar to font colour (as evidenced by word processor UIs), and can be implemented with very similar markup if you use <span style>, but not if you use <font>

[06:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
so using <font> introduces an unnecessary distinction between those similar concepts

[06:32:00.0000] <hsivonen>
/me notes that <font color> is one special thing compared to style="" like @summary is one special legacy thing compared to aria-describedby

[06:32:01.0000] <Philip`>
which makes everything harder to understand, and is more fragile when e.g. syndicators strip style attributes but not font elements

[06:32:02.0000] <jgraham>

[06:32:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:33:01.0000] <hsivonen>
otherwise, you are just picking favorites while pretending to have a principle

[12:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
on another note, is it possible to remove duplicates from a list of strings in O() less than sorting a string?

[12:07:01.0000] <Hixie>
er

[12:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
sorting the list of strings

[12:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
Yes, if you don't care about memory usage

[12:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
(e.g. have a hash-set containing all the strings you've seen so far, and for each new string you do an O(1) test to see if it's new)

[12:09:01.0000] <Philip`>
(so it ends up as O(n) if you've got n strings)

[12:09:02.0000] <Philip`>
(vs O(n log n) for sorting)

[12:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
(which doesn't seem a hugely important difference in practice, since n will usually be 1 or sometimes 2)

[02:20:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[02:21:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:28:00.0000] <hsivonen>
grr. <isindex> is an evil special case for explicit memory management

[02:28:01.0000] <hsivonen>
aarrgh

[02:29:00.0000] <hsivonen>
now I'm annoyed at both <isindex> and at C++ not having a garbage collector

[02:30:00.0000] <hsivonen>
<isindex> is fast appoaching the most-buggy feature of the V.nu parser

[02:30:01.0000] <hsivonen>
if it isn't already

[02:30:02.0000] <hsivonen>
*approaching

[02:32:00.0000] <hsivonen>
should I add refcounting for this edge case or add a special hack with 'here be dragons' comments...

[02:32:01.0000] <hsivonen>
somehow I don't like the idea of refcounting just for this one special corner case

[02:32:02.0000] <hsivonen>
anyway, yay for unit tests

[02:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
Is it very unlikely that any other feature will ever trigger the same edge case?

[02:33:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: extremely unlikely

[02:33:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: <isindex> is the only parser macro

[02:34:00.0000] <hsivonen>
where attribute names get referenced from more than one attribute holder

[02:34:01.0000] <hsivonen>
everywhere else custom attribute name objects never leave their original holder

[02:35:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I guess I'll implement ownership transfer for this case instead of burning cycles refcounting all over

[02:37:00.0000] <hsivonen>
in case anyone is interested, the problem is that non-well-known attributes are copied from the isindex token to the generated <input> element and then get freed from both

[02:38:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I'll change things so that they get moved rather than copied

[02:38:01.0000] <hsivonen>
so that the isindex token no longer has attributes when its attributes are freed

[10:38:00.0000] <mpt>
Is there a referencable summary/explanation anywhere of the principle that the accuracy of metadata is proportional to its visibility?

[10:44:00.0000] <tantek>
mpt I'm fairly certain this blog post is (one of?) the first to introduce/describe the principle: http://tantek.com/log/2005/06.html#d03t2359 "Principles of visibility and human friendliness"

[10:45:00.0000] <mpt>
thanks tantek, that's pretty much what I'm looking for

[10:47:00.0000] <tantek>
mpt - more microformats principles (in addition to visibility and human friendliness) documented here: http://microformats.org/wiki/principles

[11:09:00.0000] <hober>
mpt: related is ruby's postulate (accuracy of metadata inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the data and the metadata)

[11:09:01.0000] <mpt>
ah, that's the one I was thinking of

[11:09:02.0000] <mpt>
well, it's the form I was thinking of, but a slightly different idea

[11:09:03.0000] <hober>
from http://www.intertwingly.net/blog/2004/09/23/Copy-and-Paste

[11:10:00.0000] <tantek>
hober do you have a citation for that? we've been stating that for quite some time in the microformats community re: minimizing impact of DRY violations etc.

[11:10:01.0000] <hober>
that link is the source

[11:13:00.0000] <tantek>
thanks hober - crossed messages :)

[11:16:00.0000] <mpt>
tantek, http://intertwingly.net/slides/2004/devcon/68.html apparently dates from a few months earlier than that post (but is missing any context)

[11:17:00.0000] <hober>
visible metadata principle also relates to 'people are lazy': http://www.well.com/~doctorow/metacrap.htm#2.2

[11:18:00.0000] <mpt>
hm, no, actually, that slide is from a month later

[11:19:00.0000] <tantek>
note that per the Ruby postulate: "The accuracy of metadata is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the data and the metadata."

[11:19:01.0000] <tantek>
if the metadata IS the data itself (c.f. microformats, visible data, DRY), then the distance is 0

[11:19:02.0000] <hober>
indeed

[11:20:00.0000] <tantek>
inverse of 0 squared = infinity

[11:20:01.0000] <tantek>
ergo the most accurate metadata is to not have separate metadata at all and just use the data as metadata.

[11:23:00.0000] <hober>
right. given the 'people are lazy' thing, there's no reason to expect people to update content separated at all from the content they /have to/ update.

[11:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
tantek: In that case it's not metadata at all, it's just data :-p

[11:30:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me thought the inverse of 0^2 was undefined :P

[11:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
Depends on how you define it

[11:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you define it to be defined, then it's not undefined

[11:44:00.0000] <tantek>
gsnedders - you can define it via Ruby's formula and limits. Calculus 101.

[11:57:00.0000] <gsnedders>
"Ruby's formula"? Googling it comes up with nothing useful…

[11:58:00.0000] <jgraham>
gsnedders: The one above...

[11:58:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Oh, just that

[11:59:00.0000] <jgraham>
(Although I would really be impressed o see evidence for the squared number rather than just an assertion :) )

[12:00:00.0000] <jgraham>
(if people are going to take it seriously)

[12:08:00.0000] <tantek>
jgraham , indeed, which is specifically why I chose the word "hypotheses" for this blog post which also mentions inverse (geometric) proportionality: http://tantek.com/log/2007/02.html#d19t1813
