[06:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
"The ideal situation:  you can take any HTML5 document, convert it to some XML-based language designed for the purpose (not necessarily XHTML), convert it back, and get a semantically equivalent HTML5 document."

[06:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
That seems trivial - just output <html5><![CDATA[<!doctype html><title>foo</title>...]]></html5>

[06:31:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Brillant!

[06:32:00.0000] <Dashiva>
You could also print it out and take a picture of it, and store the image as XML

[06:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://thedailywtf.com/Articles/Interesting-Bitmap.aspx

[06:33:01.0000] <jgraham>
You mean like <pixel><red>1</red><green>1</green><blue>1</blue></pixel>

[06:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: That's not very extensible

[06:45:01.0000] <Philip`>
You need to be able to cope with multiple bit-depths

[06:46:00.0000] <Philip`>
and floating-point pixel values too

[06:46:01.0000] <Philip`>
and that needs to be configurable per pixel, so you can losslessly merge multiple images into one

[06:48:00.0000] <annevk42>
<!doctype html><title></title>]]> mwaha

[06:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
annevk42: Obviously any characters like ']' or '&' or U+0000 etc in the input will get converted to '&#nnn;' before you put the <html5><![CDATA[ wrapper around it

[06:53:00.0000] <annevk42>
oooh :p

[07:00:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: To be fair I was assuming pure floating point pixels :)

[07:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: That's not going to work if I want a pixel to be precisely a third of maximum brightness

[07:02:00.0000] <jgraham>
What if I want a pixel to be exactly 1/pi of the maximum brightness?

[07:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
You would write a schema for your pixel brightnesses, then use its URI as the namespace for your component elements

[07:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
(The schema would look like <pixel:schema xmlns:pixel="..."><pixel:type id="eightbit"><pixel:max inclusive="1">255</pixel:max><pixel:min inclusive="1">0</pixel:min><pixel:descr>Linear mapping from value onto pre-gamma brightness</pixel:descr></pixel:type></pixel:schema> with an equivalent bit for your 1/pi scale)

[15:32:01.0000] <annevk2>

[15:37:00.0000] <expensivelesbian>

[15:38:00.0000] <billyjackass>

[15:38:02.0000] <billyjackass>

[15:40:00.0000] <billyjackass>

[00:06:00.0000] <heycam>
Hixie, ping?

[00:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
here

[00:08:00.0000] <heycam>
so i'm thinking about your [XXX]es that are meant to be like "partial" interfaces

[00:08:01.0000] <heycam>
and i see that they all only have attributes on them, no operations

[00:09:00.0000] <heycam>
so that means what you really want is to avoid having a new object in the prototype chain for objects implementing these interfaces

[00:09:01.0000] <heycam>
e.g. you don't want a new, empty prototype object in the chain that corresponds to the interface with the applets attribute on it

[00:10:00.0000] <heycam>
but, i don't think "extending" the interfaces, at the IDL level, is the right thing to do

[00:10:01.0000] <heycam>
you just want to control the JS aspects of it

[00:10:02.0000] <heycam>
so e.g. if these extended interfaces did have operations, then they would go on to the HTMLDocument prototype object (in this case)

[00:13:00.0000] <heycam>
well actually i see you have two kinds of XXXes now

[00:13:01.0000] <heycam>
on WindowModal, where you separate it because sometimes you want this interface to be implemented and sometimes not, but if it is, then there's no extra object in the prototype chain for WindowModal

[00:14:00.0000] <heycam>
and for the things in the Obsolete section, where they're separate just so you don't see them in the earlier sections

[00:14:01.0000] <heycam>
but they are actually part of the same interface

[00:16:00.0000] <heycam>
ok maybe i'm talking myself into allowing "partial" interface definitions

[00:16:01.0000] <heycam>
for that second case

[00:16:02.0000] <heycam>
even though it's only because of how you want to organise the spec

[00:16:03.0000] <heycam>
but for the WindowModal case i think your XXX does need to be something like NoPrototypeObject

[00:19:00.0000] <heycam>
maybe partial should also exist to support adding new constants from different specs, like DOMException codes

[00:22:00.0000] <heycam>
also, i'm thinking of moving a bunch of things from extended attributes into the "proper" syntax

[00:22:01.0000] <heycam>
like optional arguments, variadic operations

[00:23:00.0000] <heycam>
i'm gonna give up pretending web idl is a superset of omg idl

[00:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
(still here, hold on)

[00:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
heycam: basically my desire is to not have the spec separation affect the prototype chain

[00:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
heycam: so we should be able to take, e.g., HTMLDocument, or Window, and split it amongst multiple specs and have zero effect on implementation requirements

[00:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
heycam: basically i'm trying to avoid the problem hsivonen mentions regularly where you end up splitting the tech into silos per wg

[00:30:00.0000] <heycam>
so, having a [NoPrototypeObject] could do that

[00:30:01.0000] <heycam>
especially if the interface only has attributes, since they never go in prototype objects

[00:30:02.0000] <Hixie>
they'll have methods sometimes

[00:30:03.0000] <Hixie>
i'm surprised that they don't already

[00:31:00.0000] <heycam>
maybe something like [AugmentPrototype=Window] instead

[00:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
yes

[00:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
that would work

[00:31:03.0000] <Hixie>
and then the "actual" interface name wouldn't matter?

[00:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
i.e. it'd be an editorial concern only?

[00:32:01.0000] <heycam>
yes, except for other language bindings

[00:32:02.0000] <heycam>
which don't have prototypes

[00:32:03.0000] <Hixie>
well for bindings that have classes i'd want the same thing

[00:32:04.0000] <heycam>
they'd be proper, separate interfaces still

[00:32:05.0000] <heycam>
yeah?

[00:32:06.0000] <Hixie>
the idea is for there to be zero differences

[00:32:07.0000] <heycam>
how should it matter?

[00:32:08.0000] <heycam>
if you say "all HTMLDocument objects also implement HTMLDocumentObselete"

[00:33:00.0000] <heycam>
oh casting would matter

[00:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
don't you have to explicitly cast from one to the other?

[00:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
right

[00:33:03.0000] <heycam>
i mean, you'd need to cast

[00:33:04.0000] <heycam>
hmm

[00:33:05.0000] <heycam>
so it sounds like you exactly want a "partial" modifier on interface

[00:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
the point is we should be able to take HTML5, 10 years from now, when it's all perfectly implemented (hah), and make 15 specs out of it and be able to release that as an Edited Recommendation that has zero changes required to any test suites in any languages

[00:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
with all the same code working unchanged

[00:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
that's basically what i'm doing, btw -- taking DOM2 HTML, and splitting it into the "obsolete" and "today" sections in html5

[00:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
10 years after DOM2 HTML was published

[00:36:00.0000] <heycam>
ok i'm gonna go for a "partial" keyword then, see how it goes

[00:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
cool

[00:36:02.0000] <heycam>
partial interface HTMLDocument : ... { /* now stuff */ };   partial interface HTMLDocument { /* old stuff */ };

[00:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
do i put it on all interfaces?

[00:37:01.0000] <heycam>
hmm

[00:37:02.0000] <heycam>
you want any interface to be extendable?

[00:37:03.0000] <Hixie>
i'm sure there will be specs that add to Window if there aren't already

[00:37:04.0000] <heycam>
right

[00:37:05.0000] <Hixie>
and it would have been nice to be able to add to HTMLElement instead of having the side interfaces, for some cases

[00:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
but i dunno

[00:38:01.0000] <heycam>
yeah i'm not sure

[00:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
i mean, if we have to have it to extend, you're basically saying it's the opposite of "final"

[00:38:03.0000] <heycam>
well, not really

[00:38:04.0000] <heycam>
you can extend with ":"

[00:38:05.0000] <heycam>
but it's a different kind of extending

[00:38:06.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[00:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
":" and also with "side" interfaces

[00:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
like how EventTarget is on all Nodes

[00:39:02.0000] <heycam>
right

[00:39:03.0000] <heycam>
depends on how you want the prototype chain to look

[00:39:04.0000] <Hixie>
but for some cases like Window that seems... wrong

[00:39:05.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[00:39:06.0000] <heycam>
yeah Window is a bit special in that regard, in that you think of it as just a pool of properties that you add to

[00:39:07.0000] <Hixie>
i guess in practice people would just say that the interface they want to extend had "partial" on it

[00:39:08.0000] <Hixie>
even if it didn't

[00:40:00.0000] <heycam>
heh perhaps

[00:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
so in practice even if you say we have to put it on both, it won't matter

[00:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's just nice to annotate one of them (the "not primary" one, there's usually a clear one that is the "primary" one) as being an extention of another

[00:42:00.0000] <heycam>
it's kinda weird for languages like java to have an interface whose definition changes depending on which specs you decide to implement

[00:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
why?

[00:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
how is that different from when you decide how much of one spec to implement?

[00:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's not like spec boundaries reflect actual implementation boundaries, like, ever

[00:44:00.0000] <heycam>
it's different if you want to use two libraries together, say

[00:44:01.0000] <heycam>
let's say a spec first defines interface A

[00:44:02.0000] <heycam>
and a later spec defines an extension to A

[00:44:03.0000] <heycam>
and both of these specs used this "partial" keyword to allow this

[00:45:00.0000] <heycam>
one library was compiled with the first A, and another library was compiled with the extended A

[00:45:01.0000] <heycam>
now both libraries have different A.class files

[00:45:02.0000] <heycam>
whichever one the class loader finds first is the one that will be usable

[00:45:03.0000] <heycam>
you need to be sure to get the extended one loaded first somehow

[00:46:00.0000] <heycam>
but then it's impossible if there were two extensions to A, and each library chose the different extended one

[00:46:01.0000] <heycam>
you couldn't get both libraries working together in the one program

[00:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
what about if you use two libraries, and they both implement a part of the same spec?

[00:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
same problem

[00:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
literally the same problem, because the next day that spec might be split into two

[00:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
and the day after that the specs might be merged together again

[00:49:01.0000] <heycam>
you could at least have the same all-in-one interface implemented by both libraries, but some of those methods just throw a NotImplementedException or something

[00:49:02.0000] <heycam>
in fact you would need to, to get it to compile

[00:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
i guess in java maybe. in javascript we encourage implementations that don't support something to not expose it, so that you can test to see if it exists

[00:50:01.0000] <heycam>
yes

[00:51:00.0000] <heycam>
it's a benefit of not having to implement a whole interface i suppose

[00:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
well it's a benefit of easy reification 

[00:52:00.0000] <heycam>
benefit of duck typing (sorta)?

[00:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
vaguely

[00:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
not exclusively though

[00:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's a benefit of late binding and easy reification

[00:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
sorry, not reification, reflection

[00:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
late binding and reflection

[00:54:02.0000] <Hixie>
because you can compile code that uses something without it needing to be supported, and then you can test to see if that code would work, and if it doesn't, you can skip it

[00:57:00.0000] <heycam>
so for something like WindowTimers, would you want to do that with partial instead?

[01:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[01:01:01.0000] <Hixie>
actually no

[01:01:02.0000] <Hixie>
well

[01:01:03.0000] <Hixie>
gah, i dunno

[01:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
WindowTimers is also implemented by the WorkerUtils object

[01:02:01.0000] <heycam>
ah

[01:02:02.0000] <Hixie>
but i'd want it to appear on the prototype of WorkerUtils (which itself should just appear on the prototype of two other interfaces), and i'd want it to appear as if it was part of Window also

[01:02:03.0000] <Hixie>
and it's specced in the same spec as Window but not the same spec as WorkerUtils

[01:03:00.0000] <heycam>
do any of these use ":"?

[01:03:01.0000] <heycam>
or is it [ImplementedOn]

[01:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
none of these use :

[01:04:01.0000] <heycam>
btw i think i like the "Node implements EventTarget;" kind of syntax

[01:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
oh actually that's a lie

[01:04:03.0000] <Hixie>
the WorkerUtils thing is implemented on interfaces that do use inheritance

[01:05:00.0000] <heycam>
[AugmentPrototype] Window implements WindowTimers;

[01:05:01.0000] <heycam>
or if you're doing something with ":"

[01:06:00.0000] <heycam>
interface ExtendedWindow : [AugmentPrototype] Window ...

[01:06:01.0000] <heycam>
but have Java interfaces change depending on which specs you choose to implement seems bad to me

[01:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
well i don't really mind how you end up doing things for java really

[01:07:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm mildly professionally interested in how what you do ends up for C++, because of Native Client's use of WebIDL

[01:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
but really my interest lies in JS

[01:09:00.0000] <heycam>
having c++ classes with different members seems as bad as with java

[01:09:01.0000] <heycam>
mixin abstract classes (just like different java interfaces) seems ok though

[16:39:04.0000] <Hixie>

[05:35:01.0000] <JohnResig>

[05:35:02.0000] <JohnResig>
ok, hang on, I should probably keep reading

[05:35:03.0000] <gsnedders>
JohnResig: Is CSS 3 selectors really need to be a prerequisite for the selectors test suite, though?

[05:36:00.0000] <JohnResig>
gsnedders: for a fully interoperable implementation, yep!

[05:36:01.0000] <gsnedders>
JohnResig: How so? What in selectors requires CSS 3 selectors to be tested?

[05:38:00.0000] <JohnResig>
gsnedders: I'm saying that if we care about having interoperability - and making sure that all of the possible selectors work correctly - we need to test the full gamut of CSS selectors. A number of bugs were caught in the implementations of WebKit, Firefox and Opera since these tests existed - stripping them out will mean 1) There will be regressions 2) That IE will implement more bugs in their implementation and 3) That the implementations will be more li

[05:39:00.0000] <gsnedders>
JohnResig: Is that not an issue for the CSS 3 selectors test suite, though?

[05:39:01.0000] <JohnResig>
gsnedders: no - it's simply assumed that ass CSS selectors work identically as they do in the browser - it's very likely that they don't

[05:39:02.0000] <annevk5>
gsnedders, that test suite does not test them in the context of the Selectors API

[05:40:00.0000] <JohnResig>
there were a number of selectors that failed in the suite but "passed" in the official CSS selector test suite

[05:42:00.0000] <Lachy>
JohnResig, no, I didn't say we should remove them.

[05:42:01.0000] <JohnResig>
Lachy: heh, ok, I'm still reading

[05:42:02.0000] <JohnResig>
Lachy: just got a little flustered ;)

[05:43:00.0000] <Lachy>
Just that counting them when working out IE's level of conformance isn't really fair, because not supporting CSS3 doesn't affect their conformance with the requirements in Selectors API

[05:43:01.0000] <gsnedders>
/me would nevertheless argue that unless the Selectors API requires support for CSS 3 Selectors (normatively) its test suite should just check against CSS 2.1, and optionally CSS 3 Selectors

[05:44:00.0000] <JohnResig>
Lachy: I see, yeah - and the fact that there's been 3 nearly-conformant implementations (as you pointed out) kind of removes the need for IE to be fully conformant

[05:44:01.0000] <JohnResig>
regardless

[05:45:00.0000] <JohnResig>
Lachy: I'm reading over the list on the bottom now

[05:45:01.0000] <Philip`>
roc: Why so crazy? It's just like downloading seekable media resources, except with lots more seeking, so you could add some kind of batching, and then it'd be trivial! :-)

[05:45:02.0000] <JohnResig>
Lachy: the test suite was actually, originally, xhtml - and included SVG inside of it

[05:45:03.0000] <JohnResig>
Lachy: I removed it because it broke in IE and we wanted the suite to run in IE :-/

[05:46:00.0000] <Lachy>
as far as selectors api conformance is concerned, for interoperability, we only need to ensure that the selectors that the implementations do support work correctly in the API. Requiring that they also work with Selectors that the implementation don't even claim support is silly

[05:47:00.0000] <Lachy>
ok. In that case, it's probably easiest to just make a new version that tests XHTML/SVG specific stuff

[23:53:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:54:04.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:55:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:55:04.0000] <annevk5>

[23:55:05.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:55:06.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:56:00.0000] <annevk5>

[23:57:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:57:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:15:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[00:15:04.0000] <heycam>

[00:16:00.0000] <heycam>
in its extensibility section

[00:16:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah, good

[00:16:02.0000] <heycam>

[00:17:00.0000] <heycam>

[08:45:07.0000] <jgraham>
Anyway, like I said, the big philosopical divide I see is beteen people who view writing a language as basically an engineering problem (we have to provide features x y and z so we will have markup corresponding to x y and z) and people wwho view it as a HCI problem (we have to maximise the chance that users are exposed to the features x y and z and that they are used in the right way)

[09:03:01.0000] <takkaria>

[09:04:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me finds a program which appears to have a self-defeating anti-debugging mechanism

[10:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you run an expired trial version, it (presumably) checks some files or registry entries (on Windows) to decide it's expired, and then complains

[10:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
but if you run Process Monitor, to attempt to see which files/entries it's checking, it appears to skip the checks entirely and acts as if it's non-expired

[10:32:01.0000] <Philip`>
(presumably to prevent you easily reverse-engineering it and working out what it's checking)

[10:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
so all you need to do is keeping Process Monitor running in the background all the time

[14:14:00.0000] <atwilson>
I have a question about built-in constructors, and what the behavior should be if you pass a constructor to a different window or frame.

[14:16:00.0000] <atwilson>
Let's say I pass the window.XMLHttpRequest constructor into a child frame. That child frame uses the constructor to instantiate an XHR object. Does the XHR object get the origin from the originating window (the window that the XHR constructor came from) or from the calling scope (the child frame)?

[14:16:01.0000] <atwilson>
I have a similar question about Worker objects, but I figure there's probably a general principle at work here but I don't know where in the spec I might look for it.

[14:18:00.0000] <ap>
atwilson: I don't remember the rules, but the current behavior is a result of many tweaks and fixes - so there's chance that it's correct

[14:19:00.0000] <ap>
atwilson: sorry, didn't notice where we are :)

[14:19:01.0000] <ap>
atwilson: I was talking about WebKit

[14:19:02.0000] <atwilson>
ap: The reason I ask is the WebKit behavior for XHR differs from the WebKit behavior for Workers.

[14:19:03.0000] <atwilson>
ap: so I wanted to see the actual spec.

[14:20:00.0000] <atwilson>
ap: (per the recent webkit-dev thread)

[14:21:00.0000] <ap>
atwilson: like <http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/XMLHttpRequest-2/#origin-and-base-url>?

[14:21:01.0000] <ap>
atwilson: I think that annevk2 was going to update that though

[14:22:00.0000] <atwilson>
ap: yes, but I'm not sure how to parse that spec language.

[14:23:00.0000] <atwilson>
ap: how does one determine 'which is the Document object associated with the Window object for which the XMLHttpRequest interface was created'? 

[14:24:00.0000] <ap>
atwilson: I think we should wait for Anne to weigh in on whether this text in in flux indeed

[14:24:01.0000] <atwilson>
Just look up the scope chain to find the global scope, and use the Window object associated with that? Because if that's the spec, then we aren't doing that in WebKit.

[14:24:02.0000] <atwilson>
Agreed. And I'm only using XHR as an example - the same issue applies to Workers.

[14:25:00.0000] <atwilson>
ap: Worker lifecycle depends on what document a given Worker is associated with, so making sure we associate with the correct Window is important.

[14:32:00.0000] <othermaciej_>
atwilson: XMLHttpRequest is totally clear on what to do

[14:33:00.0000] <othermaciej_>
(in my opinion)

[14:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and I am quite sure WebKit matches the intended spec behavior

[14:33:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Web Workers is a bit less clear

[14:33:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the only use of an original Window or Document would be for resolving a relative script URL against a base

[14:33:04.0000] <othermaciej>
it says to resolve the URL but it's not very clear about the base

[14:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
my assumption is it should work like Location, which would mean the calling function's global object's current document is right

[14:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
atwilson: the intent of the spec (as I understand it) is that whenever the XMLHttpRequest object is first instantiated by retrieving it from a particular Window object, it should record that Window object's current Document

[14:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
WebKit records the Window instead of the Document

[14:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I can't remember if this makes an observable difference

[14:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
there is definitely no looking up the scope chain involved

[14:40:00.0000] <ap>
othermaciej: I think the difference is that we record the window in constructor, not just in XMLHttpRequest object

[14:40:01.0000] <ap>
othermaciej: an I think that Anne was going to update the spec in this regard

[14:47:00.0000] <othermaciej>
ap: I see, the spec is probably wrong then

[14:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>
ap: I find its use of "the XMLHttpRequest object" a little confusing

[14:47:02.0000] <othermaciej>
hard to tell if it means an instance, or the constructor

[14:48:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's "Window object for which the XMLHttpRequest interface object was created" that is unclear I guess

[15:00:00.0000] <atwilson>
othermaciej: yeah, if the spec is updated to reflect that the Window is bound to the constructor rather than to any given instance, then the spec is clear (and matches WebKit).

[15:01:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
aren't interface objects and constructors different things?

[15:01:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
window.XMLHttpRequest - interface object

[15:01:02.0000] <zcorpan_>
new XMLHttpRequest() - constructor

[15:02:00.0000] <atwilson>
Hixie: Do you have an opinion about how WebWorkers should work (if I pass window.Worker into a child frame, and then the child frame instantiates a Worker using that passed-in constructor, which document object ends up in that Worker's document set)?

[15:04:00.0000] <atwilson>
zcorpan_: Quite possibly. I'm trying to find out where 'interface object' is defined in the spec now. I can't find that string in the HTML5 spec when I search for it, although it is referenced in the XHR spec.

[15:04:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
atwilson: it's defined in webidl

[15:04:02.0000] <zcorpan_>
constructors too

[15:05:00.0000] <atwilson>
awesome, I'll look there. Thanks for the pointer.

[15:06:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
(though maybe a constructor is always also an interface object in implementations?)

[15:08:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
"An ECMAScript implementation supporting these interfaces would have a [[Construct]] property on the Circle interface object which would return a new object that implements the interface."

[15:09:00.0000] <atwilson>
The XHR spec is much clearer now, since it's clear that the constructor is bound to the originating window (i.e. var f = window.XMLHttpRequest; var xhr = new f(); yields an XHR object bound to the original window, regardless of what context new f() was invoked in)

[15:12:00.0000] <atwilson>
It sounds like Workers operate differently, though - the owning document seems to be tied to a "script's global scope".

[15:12:01.0000] <atwilson>
(section 4.5 of the Web Workers spec)

[15:17:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
it seems webidl allows [NoInterfaceObject] [Constructor] interface Foo {}

[15:17:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
which makes no sense in ecmascript

[15:38:00.0000] <Hixie>

[07:55:02.0000] <jgraham>
Is there a good/standard way of empirically determining the big-O of a function? 

[07:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
What do you count as "empirical"?

[07:56:01.0000] <jgraham>
At least under some reasonable set of assumptions e.g. the function has to be drawn from a finite set

[07:56:02.0000] <jgraham>
s/function/big O function/

[07:57:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
http://forums.whatwg.org/viewtopic.php?t=4101 - spam or not?

[07:57:01.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Say I have an implementation of a "sort" function and I want to know if it is quadratic or subquadratic purely by black box measurement

[07:58:00.0000] <jgraham>
In a way that is reasonably robust against the environment

[07:58:01.0000] <Lachy>
JohnResig, I just sent a revised copy of the selectors api exit criteria to public-webapps, which also describes what should be done with the testsuite. Let me know what you think, and if and when you'll be able to make those changes

[07:59:00.0000] <jgraham>
zcorpan_: spam

[07:59:01.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: It's not possible to determine a theoretically correct answer - the function could have cost n^1.5 + n^2/1000000000, and it would be O(n^2) but all your black box measurements would make you think it was O(n^1.5)

[08:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
(The definition of big-O notation is that it's all about what happens in the limit, and you can't perform measurements in the limit)

[08:01:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Indeed. So lets say that we don't care so much about the true asymptotic behaviour but the behaviour for some reasonable range of input values

[08:01:01.0000] <jgraham>
Which isn't the theoretically pure case but is more practically interesting

[08:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
Then you can just run it for a range of n values, and pass it into some statistical analysis package (e.g. Excel's graph plotter) and get it to tell you the polynomial equation of the curve

[08:02:01.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Right but does that seem likely to be robust in the face of environmental factors

[08:03:00.0000] <jgraham>
like, say, GC pauses or whatever

[08:03:01.0000] <jgraham>
and there are practical concerns about the range of input values that should be chosen

[08:03:02.0000] <Philip`>
(There's also the issue that big-O is technically about worst case behaviour, and e.g. quicksort has terrible worst-case behaviour but you'll never notice that except on carefully-chosen inputs)

[08:04:00.0000] <jgraham>
(Yeah the worst-case behaviour thing is a reasonable concern but we'll ignore that for now)

[08:04:01.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: It seems likely to be sufficiently robust that the difference between n log n and n^2 would be blatantly obvious

[08:05:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: OK but you are not aware of any useful prior art on doing this kind of meaurement?

[08:05:01.0000] <Philip`>
I don't see why it's a complicated enough issue that one would need prior art, rather than just measuring some values and looking to see what the curve is like :-)

[08:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
or looking at the implementation and working out what it's doing

[08:06:01.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: I have been told that this is harder in practice than it sounds in theory :)

[08:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
(In the latter case, see e.g. Knuth for more information than you ever wanted to know about sorting algorithms)

[08:07:01.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: I guess it depends on how precise an answer you want

[08:07:02.0000] <Philip`>
e.g. n log n vs n^2 is easy to detect, but n^1.99 vs n^2 would be much harder

[08:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose the problem is I don't understand what problem you're trying to solve

[08:11:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Fair enough :) 

[08:12:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me isn't quite sure either

[08:12:01.0000] <Philip`>
Easy solution: Just use heap sort

[08:12:02.0000] <Philip`>
Uh, merge sort

[08:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think that's the one I mean

[08:15:00.0000] <zcorpan_>

[09:07:00.0000] <jgraham>
(for legacy UAs or for super-complex corner cases or something)

[09:07:01.0000] <Philip`>
Is summary="Calendar" considered a useful use of summary? That's something that's very hard to determine algorithmically, and hard for someone using a non-graphical browser to determine, but trivial for someone using a graphical browser

[09:08:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: That's not what @summary is for, apparently

[09:08:01.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, I don't think so

[09:08:02.0000] <jgraham>
(my current understanding is that it is _only_ supposed to be used for describing the structure of the table)

[09:08:03.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: It doesn't really matter what it's apparently for, it matters whether it's beneficial to users

[09:09:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
would be interesting to see if it's possible to determine whether a given table is a calendar or not

[09:09:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
calendars usually have a specific format

[09:09:02.0000] <Lachy>
"This attribute provides a summary of the table's purpose and structure ..." - For most common simple cases, it's possible to determine the structure simply by looking at the headings. The purpose should be indicated by the caption or surrounding prose.

[09:15:00.0000] <beowulf>
if the ua can't provide a summary, allow the author to use @summary or whatever, no?

[09:16:00.0000] <Lachy>
beowulf, even if the UA can't, there are better proposals than the @summary

[09:42:00.0000] <remysharp>
hi - I've been playing with the manifest for offline apps in Safari, and checking the docs because Safari won't reload a server side change - is this being handled correctly?

[09:42:01.0000] <remysharp>
i.e. the page is loaded and told to cache xyz assets

[09:42:02.0000] <remysharp>

[09:42:04.0000] <remysharp>

[09:43:01.0000] <remysharp>

[09:44:00.0000] <ap>

[10:06:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: is it possible to generate messages that say what to use instead for obsolete attributes?

[10:12:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan_: yeah, it's possible to do with the assertions-checking code

[10:12:01.0000] <remysharp>
ap: cheers for the help.

[10:12:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan_: anything is possible with that. we can make the error messages say whatever we want

[10:13:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: i think it would be useful to rip off what Hixie wrote in the obsolete section

[10:14:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: hmm, actually

[10:14:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: some messages already have the content model stuff

[10:15:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan_: yeah, for some cases

[10:15:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: maybe it would make sense to include a separate field in a similar manner for advice on what to use instead

[10:15:02.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: instead of adding everything to the schema and assertions

[10:17:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
we can't add arbitrary messages to the grammar-based schema checking anyway. we are stuck with what Jing reports there, for the most part

[10:17:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the content-model stuff that hsivonen has it emitting now is something that he hooked in with custom code

[10:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
it just copies that from a copy of the spec, verbatim

[10:18:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: can't the advice be implemented the same as the content model stuff?

[10:19:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
it could be, but it would be more trouble than just adding it to the assertions checking

[10:19:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
ok

[10:19:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
the assertions checking is now implemented as custom Java code anyway

[10:19:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
so we can do anything we want with that

[10:19:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
there is still the assertions.sch file, but v.nu doesn't actually use that

[10:20:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
aha

[10:20:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, v.nu has an mechanism already for emitting Info-class messages (as opposed to Error or Warning)

[10:20:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
so that part's already in there

[10:21:00.0000] <zcorpan_>
i was having in mind including the advice in the same error message

[10:21:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
like content model stuff is tied to a an error message

[10:22:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I think it would need to be Info so that users can suppress it if they want

[10:22:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
IMHO, that's how the content-model stuff should be too

[10:22:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
they can still be tied together

[10:23:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
could just think of them as different fields of the same message

[10:24:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, I chatted with hsivonen a while back of using the assertions-checking backend for more cases, particularly cases where the error messages from Jing aren't very useful

[10:24:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
which is actually a lot of cases

[10:24:02.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmith: some parse errors already have advice on what to do instead

[10:25:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, the error messages for parse errors is another separate thing

[10:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
as far as the schema-checking part goes, I think one lesson from this is that you can't ever expect to get useful messages for all cases from a grammar-based generic checker like Jing or any other RelaxNG or XSD checker

[10:28:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
if you want good error messages for more cases, it has to be supplemented with other kinds of checking

[10:28:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
schematron assertion-based checking is actually a really good way

[10:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but the performance sucks

[10:30:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and it is based on XPath, and not everybody likes XPath, and writing XPath expressions for some cases is a PITA

[10:31:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me onders how the fraction of custom java code in validator.nu has changed as a function of time

[10:31:01.0000] <jgraham>
+w

[10:31:02.0000] <zcorpan_>
so the conclusion is to use relax ng for anything that doesn't need useful messages and custom code for the rest?

[10:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
jgraham: the custom code for assertion checking has been going down recently because Hixie has relaxed or removed some constraints

[10:32:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
like the one about encoding declaration needing to be first child of head

[10:32:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
or around datagrid content model

[10:33:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the datagrid content-model checking was a big chunk of the assertions code

[10:33:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan_: no, not exactly -- not IMHO at least

[10:33:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
though that is basically what v.nu is doing now

[10:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
well, not exactly

[10:34:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
lemme rephrase that

[10:35:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
v.nu now is mostly using relax ng for anything that can be expressed practically in relax ng, and then using the assertions checking for stuff that can't, as then other custom code for stuff that can't be done with assertions checking (e.g., overlapping table cells)

[10:36:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so relax ng does emit useful messages for a lot of cases

[10:36:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but there are some others where it doesn't -- like cases that Rick Jelliffe mentioned

[10:37:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., where the constraint is around allowed sequences of elements

[10:47:00.0000] <webben_>
/me notes that one major advantage of DTD-based validation is developers can hack the DTD to change the constraints. I don't think that offsets the way DTDs limit what you can check, but it is a major advantage nevertheless.

[10:48:00.0000] <webben_>
e.g. at Yahoo!, we're on route to using a custom DTD internally for validating the sub- and super-sets of HTML4 we want to be using.

[10:48:01.0000] <brale>

[10:50:00.0000] <zcorpan>
webben_: you can hack a relax ng schema, too

[10:51:00.0000] <webben_>
zcorpan: Oh absolutely, and I much prefer that.

[10:52:00.0000] <webben_>

[10:52:01.0000] <webben_>

[10:53:00.0000] <webben_>
so there our immediate approach is to try to comment out bits of CSS we know won't validate

[10:53:01.0000] <webben_>
which is problematic in itself.

[10:59:00.0000] <webben_>

[10:59:01.0000] <webben_>

[11:00:00.0000] <webben_>

http://code.google.com/intl/es/speed/articles/optimizing-html.html

[02:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:52:01.0000] <Philip`>
Adding </li>s and </p>s (with any necessary whitespace to http://www.google.com/intl/en/privacy.html makes the file 251 bytes larger, and makes the gzipped file 7 bytes larger

[02:52:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:52:03.0000] <Philip`>

[02:53:02.0000] <Philip`>

[03:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
fundamentally, if two groups have contradictory goals (in this case "make it possible to write fully-accessible pages even if the overall quality of pages is lower than with other approaches" and "improve the overall quality of pages so that more are accessible even if the theoretical maximum accessibility is lower than with other approaches"), they won't come to an agreement

[03:13:01.0000] <jgraham>
Hixie: To be fair there has been some acknoledgement that it hasn't worked. It is just that they consider that it is important to have it even though it hasn't worked in general; either because they think it might work well in the future or because they think experts can use it and only experts matter

[03:13:02.0000] <Hixie>

[03:14:00.0000] <Hixie>

[03:52:04.0000] <Lachy>
I'm not convinced of the need to have such explicit assocation. Just summarise the table in the preceding paragraph

[03:53:00.0000] <Lachy>
so <p>This is a summary of the following table...</p><table>...</table>

[03:54:00.0000] <jgraham>

[03:54:01.0000] <jgraham>

[03:57:00.0000] <Lachy>
I'm sure they did. That doesn't mean they're right. I haven't seen any usability studies demonstrating how effective or ineffective a summary would be if it doesn't have an explicit association in the markup

[03:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
In the absence of any usability studies (because presumably the WG doesn't care enough about accessibility to actually do any), the best information we have about user behaviour is what users claim

[04:05:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, sure, but anyone in the field of usability knows you should avoid giving too much weight to what the user says, as their behaviour can often completely contradict that

[04:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: Indeed, but hypothesising about other people's behaviour is likely to be even less accurate, and we don't currently have any other sources of information

[04:08:00.0000] <Lachy>

[04:09:00.0000] <Lachy>

[16:39:00.0000] <beowulf>

[16:41:00.0000] <sayrer>
beowulf, prescriptivists have a tough time telling a descriptivist from an anarchist, so there HTML anarchists in the minds of some

[16:45:00.0000] <beowulf>
sayrer: what is descriptivism in the context of HTML?

[16:46:00.0000] <sayrer>
beowulf: that would mean writing down what mean, without judging whether they're doing it wrong

[16:46:01.0000] <sayrer>
what markup means

[16:46:02.0000] <sayrer>
so for instance, @valign is banned as wrong in Ian's draft

[16:47:00.0000] <sayrer>
descriptivist approach would be to write it down, and note that the same task can be accomplished other ways (synonyms)

[16:49:00.0000] <sayrer>
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ain%27t is a could example

[16:49:01.0000] <sayrer>
good example

[16:49:02.0000] <sayrer>
"It is a word that is widely used by many people, but its use is commonly considered to be improper.[1]"

[16:50:00.0000] <beowulf>
sayrer: ah, i get you

[16:51:00.0000] <sayrer>

[16:51:01.0000] <sayrer>
people who obsess about whether they are using <dt> right

[16:51:02.0000] <sayrer>
my opinion is that the section that most precisely defines the semantics of these elements is section 11, rendering

[21:31:00.0000] <zcorpan>
html4 only allows noframes inside frameset, but the html5 parser inserts noframes to head or html for before and after respectively

[21:32:00.0000] <zcorpan>
<!doctype html><title>noframes</title><noframes></noframes><frameset><noframes></noframes></frameset><noframes></noframes>

[21:32:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[21:34:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[22:14:03.0000] <sayrer>

[22:15:00.0000] <sayrer>

[22:16:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:16:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:16:03.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: don't you mean "scare" quotes?

[22:16:04.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:16:05.0000] <othermaciej>
sayrer: I'm dubious about the value of a normative spec defining the behavior of lint tools

[22:16:06.0000] <sayrer>
I think that's what he "means"

[22:17:00.0000] <sayrer>
othermaciej: me too, that's why I don't like the current author conformance requirements

[22:17:01.0000] <othermaciej>
sayrer: however, hsivonen made the plausible argument that having a certain common level of baseline rules is an interoperability benefit for authoring tools and validators

[22:17:02.0000] <sayrer>
since there are many rules that are basically lint tool kind of things

[22:17:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
we should have double scare quotes -- e,g., ""working group"" -- to indicate an extra amount of disdain

[22:17:04.0000] <othermaciej>
that's the only really convincing argument I have heard for why such things make sense as conformance requirements

[22:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
sayrer: do you think the spec should contain any authoring conformace requirements?

[22:18:01.0000] <Dashiva>
MikeSmith: Shouldn't you use a different quote set for one of them, to avoid it parsing as "", working group, ""?

[22:18:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
heh

[22:18:03.0000] <othermaciej>
sayrer: it's not totally clear to me if you doubt the value of all of them or only some?

[22:18:04.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: I would think nested scare quotes would neutralize

[22:19:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah yeah, true

[22:19:01.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: since in general "foo" means 'people call it foo, but I don't really think it is, I'm just using their term under protest'

[22:19:02.0000] <sayrer>
othermaciej: some rules seem to be in place because the markup is "presentational"

[22:19:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
you can use them to quote somebody else's use of scare quotes -- to show disdain for the fact that they are using scare quotes

[22:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>
sayrer: are those the only kinds of rules you don't like?

[22:20:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
sayrer: very true, and not everybody is in agreement about that class of constraints

[22:20:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g, the presentational attributes on <table>

[22:20:03.0000] <othermaciej>
"make presentational markup conforming" is a pretty clear position and worth discussing on that basis

[22:21:00.0000] <sayrer>
oh, I think concrete spec text would make it easier to discuss

[22:21:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I have an easier time reading a few sentences than a whole alternate spec

[22:21:02.0000] <sayrer>
then there are those things that seem kind of vestigial or ineffective

[22:22:00.0000] <sayrer>
like @profile and @summary

[22:22:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the bulk of the kind of conformance checking that v.nu is doing is simply checks like, "you can't have a <dd> as a child of a <ul>"

[22:22:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I suspect many others are in that position

[22:22:03.0000] <sayrer>
those vestigial things hardly seem worth bannign

[22:23:00.0000] <sayrer>
or declaring invalid

[22:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
sayrer: do you think rules like what MikeSmith cited (can't have a <dd> as a child of a <ul>) are worthwhile?

[22:23:02.0000] <othermaciej>
or more specifically, are they worthwhile as conformance requirements?

[22:23:03.0000] <sayrer>
yes, that is the class of things that I have a hard time characterizing. a lint tool would clearly want to report "<b><i>foo</b></i>"

[22:24:00.0000] <sayrer>
to use a really brain dead example

[22:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
misnested tags are in some sense a different level of error than structurally sound markup that happens to violate content model rules

[22:25:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, <b><i>foo</b></i> gets reported by the parser, not validator code

[22:25:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think some people are interested in avoiding presentational markup in their output, and others are not

[22:25:02.0000] <sayrer>
for sure

[22:25:03.0000] <othermaciej>
right now the spec is a compromise and therefore doesn't fully address either need

[22:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I wonder if it would make sense to have two classes of conformance to address this

[22:26:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
"Error: End tag b violates nesting rules."

[22:26:02.0000] <sayrer>
I am in favor of an authoring guide

[22:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I think it would make sense to have user-tunable validators

[22:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if we accept Henri's premise that there needs to be a shared set of rules, so that different combinations of content generators and validators can interoperate without large switching costs, then an authoring guide may be insufficient

[22:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not sure if that premise is right

[22:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
there's a market for validators, just like there is a market for browsers

[22:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but it sounds plausible

[22:29:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
and people place value on validators

[22:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the idea being, my CMS generates markup that is error-free in Validator A, but I decide I like the user interface of Validator B better

[22:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
can I switch without being flooded with errors?

[22:30:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
right

[22:30:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that seems to be a case where interoperability matters

[22:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
so that makes me think that there has to be some shared definition of what counts as content errors

[22:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so it's not a viable position for the WG to completely fail to define authoring conformance

[22:31:02.0000] <sayrer>
I don't think any of that follows

[22:32:00.0000] <sayrer>
in particular, I am not suggesting the WG fail to define anything

[22:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not saying you are suggesting that

[22:32:02.0000] <sayrer>
ok

[22:32:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
anyway, it does at least seem that there's a fundamental baseline of document-conformance rules that we could get agreement on 

[22:32:04.0000] <othermaciej>
it is now clear to me that you think there should be some definition of what constitutes an error

[22:32:05.0000] <othermaciej>
and that at the very least, you don't think presentational markup or obsolete but harmless attributes should be in that category

[22:32:06.0000] <sayrer>
well, there are things that I would like to have attention brought to, as an author

[22:33:00.0000] <sayrer>
"this may not mean what you think it means" is something I want to know about

[22:33:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
right

[22:33:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., a <dd> as a child of <ul>

[22:34:00.0000] <sayrer>
well, what is the error you would report for that?

[22:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it's not clear to me what you think should be in that definition, or whether you think those rules should be labeled something other than "conformance", or how you feel about whether they need to be in a separate document from browser conformance rules

[22:35:00.0000] <sayrer>
1.) not sure what should be there, probably requires user testing

[22:35:01.0000] <sayrer>
2.) don't want the labeled as conformance requirements in the HTML document, somewhere else is fine

[22:35:02.0000] <sayrer>
3.) probably separate

[22:36:00.0000] <sayrer>
MikeSmith: what is the ideal error for <dd> in <ul> ?

[22:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so it's ok to label the rules conformance requirements, but not if they are in the same document as browser conformance requirements?

[22:36:02.0000] <sayrer>
yes

[22:36:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I can understand the rest of your position, but not that part

[22:37:00.0000] <sayrer>
the other conformance requirements in the document have interop ramifications

[22:37:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
sayrer: I don't know what would be ideal, but at a minimum, the checker should report, "<dd> is not allowed as a child of <ul>"

[22:37:02.0000] <sayrer>
well, it is allowed

[22:37:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
and then report what is allowed as a child of <ul>

[22:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen would argue that validity rules have interop ramifications (between different validators and different content generators)

[22:38:01.0000] <sayrer>
I find that position pretty circular

[22:38:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't see how it's circular

[22:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the idea is that you can switch content generating tools without changing validators, or vice versa

[22:39:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it's a much less important form of interoperability than browser <--> content

[22:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but being able to switch out pieces independently is pretty much what interoperability means

[22:40:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
sayrer: OK, if I get your point, the error might more precisely be, "using <dd> as a child of <ul> is probably not going to have the effect you might be expecting"

[22:40:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
sayrer: "<dd> as a child of <ul> is probably not something you want to do"

[22:41:00.0000] <sayrer>
"we need this rule so the things that check rules will have a rule"

[22:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think a more fair presentation of the position would be "we need rules about what is an error so that content producers and tools that check for content errors can agree on what is an error"

[22:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
you could say "tools that check for content errors" should not label anything they report as errors, but the same reasoning applies if you call them "errors" or "conditions that indicate the author may not have said what he meant" or whatever

[22:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
or "warnings"

[22:47:00.0000] <sayrer>
validator interop is not something the w3c is chartered to 

[22:48:00.0000] <sayrer>
to do

[22:49:00.0000] <sayrer>
I am not even sure it's desirable, but if it is, every validator implementor will rush to become  Rec FooValidator2015 or whatever

[22:49:01.0000] <sayrer>
I suppose there's a subtext of everyone being paranoid about rogue additions to the language

[22:49:02.0000] <sayrer>
but I don't think these rules are going to help that

[22:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I could buy that validator interop is not an important goal

[22:53:00.0000] <sayrer>
it would certainly be easier to suss out  if the author conformance rules had clear, uniform motivations

[22:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so far, the one validator developer who has spoken up thinks it is

[22:53:02.0000] <othermaciej>
they do seem to have different motivations

[22:54:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
sayrer: it might also help if we used the term "document conformance" instead of "authoring conformance"

[22:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there's surface syntax errors where the motivation seems to be that they are likely to indicate an error, and may result in divergent behavior in older browsers

[22:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there's nesting rules where violating them results in parser madness (like <p> not allowed in <table>) or because some elements have very fixed behavior and other children don't make sense (like <div> not being allowed in <select>)

[22:55:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: right

[22:56:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
there are also cases like, you can't nest <a href>s if you want them to have an expected effect

[22:57:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or, as a class, you can't nest interactive elements

[22:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there's nesting rules that are based on what is believed to be proper semantic structure, but which are not in any way enforced and won't cause interop problems if you violate them (like <b> not allowed immediately inside <ul>)

[22:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there's elements or attribute that have an effect but are banned because they are presentational

[22:58:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[22:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
<b> inside <ul> will cause problems to any tool that tries to do anything useful with list items in a list

[22:58:03.0000] <othermaciej>
there's elements or attributes that have no effect, and may have been in older specs, but are banned because they are useless

[22:58:04.0000] <Hixie>
(e.g. scripts that resort lists)

[22:59:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there's elements or attributes that have no current effect and were never in a spec (the general ban on unknown elements or attributes)

[22:59:01.0000] <heycam>
Hixie, "but the novice authors is cautioned" in the new "A quick introduction to HTML" section

[22:59:02.0000] <othermaciej>
there's rules for attribute values that disallow things that can't have an effect because they don't satisfy the basic syntax of the attribute (that would be in the "likely to be an error" category)

[22:59:03.0000] <Hixie>
heycam: thanks

[23:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not sure if that list of categories was exhaustive

[23:00:01.0000] <sayrer>
elements that have an effect but were never in a spec

[23:01:00.0000] <sayrer>
that's all I can think of

[23:02:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there's also mandatory content, like the fact that documents must have a <title> or that <img> elements must have a src attribute

[23:05:00.0000] <sayrer>
those last two seem different to me

[23:05:01.0000] <sayrer>
maybe it's not important

[23:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I see your point; not sure how to express the difference

[23:06:01.0000] <othermaciej>
some mandatory content is mandatory because the associated container won't work otherwise

[23:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
many elements are also required to have " at least one descendant text node that is not inter-element whitespace, or at least one descendant element node that is embedded content"

[23:07:01.0000] <othermaciej>
which effectively rules out being empty

[23:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not sure if that's in the "otherwise the element doesn't work" category of mandatory content, or the "because it seems right to require this" category

[23:08:01.0000] <sayrer>
one class of content nesting rules would seem to concern mark up where the DOM is quite different from the lexical nesting of the markup

[23:08:02.0000] <sayrer>
parser madness

[23:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if I'm reading the spec right, it seems like it is conforming for <table> or <ul> to be empty, but not for <p> or <b> to be empty

[23:12:00.0000] <sayrer>
interesting. people put empty <p> elements in to space things out quite a lot

[23:12:01.0000] <sayrer>
heretical

[23:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
empty <p> elements collapse away

[23:14:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(at least by default; you could presumably style them not to)

[23:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
you must be reading an old version of the spec

[23:15:01.0000] <Hixie>
either that or i missed some bit

[23:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
because empty <p> is explicitly allowed (though mildly discouraged) to enable scripts to fill them in later

[23:15:03.0000] <Hixie>
and to allow templates to be filled in later yet still be validated

[23:17:00.0000] <sayrer>
oh right

[23:17:01.0000] <sayrer>
must be <br>s or something when they do that

[23:19:00.0000] <sayrer>
anyway, we have quite a few axes for these rules

[23:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
<br>s?

[23:19:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I see, "flow content" non-emptiness is a SHOULD now

[04:41:02.0000] <jgraham>

[04:41:03.0000] <jgraham>

[10:20:00.0000] <webben>

[10:20:01.0000] <webben>

[10:21:00.0000] <webben>

[10:22:00.0000] <takkaria>

[10:22:01.0000] <takkaria>

[10:22:02.0000] <webben>

[10:28:00.0000] <takkaria>
I'm just annoyed at people casting aspersions without giving good reasons for casting them

[10:29:00.0000] <webben>
I think the comment should have acknowledged that AT vendors are at liberty to join the discussion; and that some AT vendors are already present in the discussion.

[10:30:00.0000] <takkaria>
I think there's also a big difference here between adding new features and evaluating existing features

[10:30:01.0000] <takkaria>
if we introduce new a11n features, AT vendors should be consulted

[10:30:02.0000] <takkaria>
but longdesc/summary are about seeing if an existing experiment has given good results or not

[10:31:00.0000] <webben>
I don't think there's any difference really.

[10:31:01.0000] <webben>
As we can see from summary, consultation can change one's interpretation of existing features.

[10:33:00.0000] <takkaria>
Murray's argument just seem to be suggesting to me that the AT people should say what a11n features we should have, and that's that

[10:35:00.0000] <webben>
takkaria: I'm not sure that is what Murray is arguing.

[10:35:01.0000] <takkaria>
maybe I'm wilfully misinterpreting given my own biases :)

[10:36:00.0000] <webben>
takkaria: Seems to me his argument is: if browser vendors are the ultimate arbiters of features, then why are AT arbiters not the ultimate arbiters of a11y features.

[10:36:01.0000] <webben>
(earlier in the email he rejects the idea that browser vendors can be trusted to get things right for their users)

[10:36:02.0000] <takkaria>
well, they are

[10:37:00.0000] <takkaria>
but the AT vendors tend to refuse to take part in the HTMLWG, so there's not much can be done about that...

[10:37:01.0000] <webben>
some AT vendors.

[10:37:02.0000] <webben>
there are certainly options for external consultation

[10:38:00.0000] <webben>
particularly with opensource projects like NVDA and Orca.

[10:39:00.0000] <webben>

[10:40:00.0000] <takkaria>
mm

[10:40:01.0000] <takkaria>
I'm just not sure we need AT people to be there to see that longdesc has failed on the web

[10:42:00.0000] <webben>
Personally, I find the idea of putting a11y features into a box and putting it at the feet of AT vendors as problematic as it would be to exclude the later from discussions of supposedly non-a11y features.

[10:42:01.0000] <webben>
there's a lot of accessibility that has little to do with AT.

[10:42:02.0000] <webben>
but is provided by authoring practice or ordinary browser features.

[10:43:00.0000] <webben>
I think the argument about the utility of "summary" to sighted users (however we choose to judge on that issue) touches directly on that.

[10:44:00.0000] <Dashiva>
webben: It also reinforces the view of accessibility as a bolt-on thing

[10:45:00.0000] <webben>
Dashiva: well the idea of "a11y feature" is itself the idea of a bolt-on thing.

[10:46:00.0000] <webben>
I don't think the notion "a11y features" might be the province of AT vendors adds much bolt-on-ed-ness.

[10:47:00.0000] <Dashiva>
The idea itself is author bolt-on, but leaving it to AT makes it a vendor bolt-on too.

[10:47:01.0000] <webben>
I see what you mean.

[10:48:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Thinking mainly of ARIA, but there might be other cases

[10:49:00.0000] <webben>
ARIA, whatever its merits, is indeed an example of AT- rather than accessibility-driven design. But then it was basically conceived as a bolt-on to Dojo widgets so that's not surprising.

[05:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
Ah

[05:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
MikeSmith: There's doctypes too, where the things that look quoted attribute strings can't contain entities

[05:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
OK

[05:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: If I had an error-correcting version of UTF16-BE, which mapped the one-byte string 0x3C (and similarly the two-byte string 0x3C 0x00) onto U+003C, would that be ASCII-compatible?

[05:22:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so if I wanted to try to have a term that unambiguously describes the contents of <script> and <style> elements, would "unparsed character data" be inaccurate?

[05:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: i... guess?

[05:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: how would it know that 0x3C was an error though?

[05:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: Because it would reach the end of the file/string and flush all unfinished characters

[05:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: "a document that is valid as two different encodings at once, with different <meta charset> elements applying in each case" - depending on what's meant by "valid", how about <meta charset=&quot;utf-8 +names"> ?

[05:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
which has charset equivalent to utf-8 if you decode as utf-8, and equivalent to utf-8+names if you decode as utf-8+names

[05:44:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
hendry: thanks for dwm+dmenu tip. I'll give it a try

[05:44:02.0000] <Philip`>
(based on http://www.tbray.org/tag/utf-8+names.html)

[05:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose what's really needed is that if a document saying <meta charset="X"> is encoded as X and then decoded as ASCII, it will still be seen to say <meta charset="X">, so the requirement is that U+003C etc must *encode* to 0x3C, and nothing else must encode to any sequence containing 0x3C etc

[05:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
s/\*encode\*/always encode/

[10:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: \x1B$@<meta/\x1B(B charset=utf-8 x="<meta charset=iso-2022-jp>">

[10:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
(where "\x1B" is the byte 0x1B)

[10:52:00.0000] <Philip`>
Decoding as UTF-8 gives charset=utf-8, decoding as ISO-2022-JP gives charset=iso-2022-jp, and ISO-2022-* looks like it would be considered "ASCII compatible" because all the normal characters (everything except 0x1B) are mapped identically to ASCII

[10:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
The charset johab/cp1361 (http://www.fileformat.info/info/charset/x-Johab/list.htm) might have similar problems, since ß is encoded as 0xDD 0x3C

[11:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
ISO-2022 is great fun

[11:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
http://search.yahoo.com/search?p=%E9%B9%BF%E5%A1%A2%E6%AF%80%E8%BB%A2%E9%A6%96%E7%AB%B0%E8%9C%B7%E5%9D%8F%20src=data:text/plain,alert(123)//&ei=UTF-8&eo=iso-2022-jp

[11:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
View that in a browser that doesn't support iso-2022, or manually switch the encoding to iso-8859-1

[11:32:01.0000] <Philip`>
Unfortunately all the browsers I tested do support iso-2022 :-(

[11:32:02.0000] <eighty4>
"123"

[11:32:03.0000] <Philip`>
but anyway it's a bit of an XSS hole

[13:33:00.0000] <Hixie>

[13:33:01.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: So it has to be conforming HTML, not just a valid byte sequence in the given encoding?

[13:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
right

[13:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: the point is to highlight these issues to authors

[13:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: so if the author gets a conformance error, that's enough

[13:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
imho

[13:35:00.0000] <Hixie>

[13:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
i understand it's actually used quite widely, at least for e-mail and maybe for web

[13:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: Is <meta charset=&quot;utf-8>+names"> conforming (in both encodings)?

[13:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
It doesn't have any unrecognised attributes now, unless I'm being stupid

[13:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://philip.html5.org/data/charsets.html#charset-iso-2022-jp - hmm, that seems to be used quite a bit

[13:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
utf-8+names isn't ascii-compatible

[13:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
so <meta charset can't be used with it

[13:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
in a conforming page

[13:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
I thought the idea was to have an example that justifies the inclusion of that ASCII-compatibility requirement

[13:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
so it just needs to conform to all other requirements

[13:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
no the idea is to have an example that justifies changing the encoding sniffer to bail as soon as it hits a byte sequence that might screw things up

[13:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
or changing the ASCII-compatibility requirements to exclude even ascii bytes in later parts of multibyte sequences

[14:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: Hmm, what about <meta charset=\x0Eutf8>x\x0Fiso2022kr>

[14:01:01.0000] <Philip`>
which is also <meta charset=朮歷없iso2022kr>

[14:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
how is that valid in 2022?

[14:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
0x0E and 0x0F are escape codes in iso-2022-kr (http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1557)

[14:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, I suppose there's the problem that 朮歷없iso2022kr isn't the preferred name for that encoding

[14:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
right

[14:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
or any name for it as far as i can tell

[14:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
I thought anything [^a-zA-Z0-9] gets stripped when comparing names

[14:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
hm i guess it would compare correctly, yeah

[14:05:02.0000] <Hixie>
but it's still not valid

[14:05:03.0000] <gsnedders>
takkaria: http://www.flickr.com/photos/takkaria/3668544285/ — Now I'm not sure it is worth it.

[14:05:04.0000] <Hixie>
it's also not valid in UTF-8, is it?

[14:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
U+000E is a parse error

[14:06:01.0000] <Hixie>

[14:06:02.0000] <Hixie>

[14:06:03.0000] <Hixie>
and btw these encodings are insane

[14:07:00.0000] <takkaria>

[14:23:00.0000] <Philip`>

2009-06-29
[18:44:00.0000] <annodomini>
Are there any features in HTML5 (other than the different parsing rules) that are currently available only in the HTML syntax and not in the XHTML syntax?

[19:04:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
annodomini: lack of support for content from arbitrary namespaces

[19:12:00.0000] <annodomini>
MikeSmith: That's a feature missing from the HTML syntax, right? I'm wondering if I'll be missing anything (other than HTML parsing, and IE compatibility) if I use XHTML.

[19:14:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
annodomini: lack of support for content from arbitrary namespaces could be considered an actual feature, not a missing feature

[19:14:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
annodomini: anyway, no, you're not going to be missing anything

[19:14:02.0000] <annodomini>
Ah, now I see.

[19:15:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but a big caveat is that if you are dynamically aggregating content from other places, you need to be very careful to make sure that content doesn't contain any well-formedness errors

[19:16:00.0000] <annodomini>
Right, that's why I mentioned the HTML parser.

[19:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
annodomini: <noscript>

[19:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
annodomini: maybe a few others

[19:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
annodomini: <svg> and <mathml> without the namespace stuff

[19:22:00.0000] <annodomini>
Hixie: Sure, you're going to have to use namespaces if you're using XML. I'm curious why <noscript> isn't supported?

[19:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
<noscript> is implemented as a weird parsing hack

[19:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
the parser actually acts differently for script-enabled browsers vs script-disabled

[19:23:02.0000] <heycam>
document.write() is another one

[19:23:03.0000] <Hixie>
which we can't do in xml

[19:23:04.0000] <Hixie>
yep, document.write() doesn't work in xml either

[19:24:00.0000] <annodomini>
Hmm. OK, so there's a non-trivial set of functionality that's not available in the XHTML syntax. Good to know.

[19:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
nothing good is missing :-)

[19:34:00.0000] <annodomini>
I'm basically wondering if I want to use XSLT to generate HTML5, if I should be trying to use XML output or HTML output.

[19:34:01.0000] <annodomini>
 If it's just parser hacks like <noscript> and document.write(), I can probably work with XML.

[19:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'd suggest not using xslt, but xml output should be good if you do want to use it (not sure how it works with IE though)

[19:36:00.0000] <annodomini>
Why would you recommend against xslt? I'm just looking into it now, so I'm curious what the disadvantages are.

[19:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm just biased against it because i get a headache when i try to use it :-)

[19:37:01.0000] <heycam>
i heartily recommend xslt!

[19:37:02.0000] <heycam>
xslt2, that is.  xslt1 is slightly painful.

[19:38:00.0000] <annodomini>
(according to my googling, you can cram xhtml through IE if you lie about its mime type and leave off the XML processing instruction because it triggers quirks mode)

[19:39:00.0000] <annodomini>
Hixie: Ah, OK. I'll decide on whether it hurts my head once I use it a bit more. At a quick glance it looks fairly reasonable for using as a basic template system; I wouldn't want to use it for much more than that.

[19:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
i tried to use it to turn an xml file of numbers into an html file of slightly different numbers and that didn't go well

[19:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
that probably soured my opinion of it

[19:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
though generally speaking i'm scared of anything that's turing complete using angle brackets in the basic syntax

[19:40:03.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. also C++ templates :-)

[19:44:00.0000] <annodomini>
heycam: What are the benefits of xslt2?

[19:44:01.0000] <annodomini>
And do the browsers support it? I'm using browser xslt support for quickly testing thing out.

[19:44:02.0000] <heycam>
annodomini, two that i find useful are being able to define your own functions with <xsl:function>

[19:45:00.0000] <heycam>
and being able to tunnel template parameters

[19:45:01.0000] <heycam>
so you don't need to explicitly pass them in

[19:45:02.0000] <heycam>
i don't think any browsers support xslt2

[19:45:03.0000] <heycam>
i just use saxon for offline document processing

[19:45:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
lack of document.write() support in XHTML is a feature

[19:46:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
support for document.write() in HTML is a bug

[19:47:00.0000] <annodomini>
Yeah, I don't mind losing that.

[19:49:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
annodomini: fwiw, I use XSLT1 for generating HTML for some things. It is painful in places, but I guess I've learned what the limitations and problems are and how to deal with them.

[19:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I've been too lazy to learn XSLT2

[19:50:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
when I have time, I plan to learn it by stealing from XSLT2 work that heycam did recently for generating the SVG spec

[19:51:00.0000] <annodomini>
I'm looking at it only as a basic template system, and not anything fancy, so I think I'll stick with XSLT1 for now.

[19:52:00.0000] <heycam>
annodomini, when you get to the point where you're writing recursive templates to step through strings a character at a time to do some simple string manipulation, that's when you know it's time to upgrade to xslt2

[19:52:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[19:52:02.0000] <annodomini>
Right. Sounds good.

[19:52:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
limitations on string manipulation in XSLT1 is a joke

[19:53:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
though there are some EXSLT things that most XSLT processors

[19:53:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
extensions that make some things easier

[19:59:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: does the spec define where escaping text spans are allowed?

[19:59:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
are they only allowed in CDATA and RCDATA elements?

[19:59:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
or are they allowed in normal elements and foreign elements?

[20:03:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, I guess the answer is that anything that might look like any escaping text span in normal elements or foreign elements is actually a comment

[20:04:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and that anything that looks like a comment in CDATA or RCDATA contents is actually an escaping text span

[20:16:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I think it's a mistake to use the term "CDATA elements" in the spec

[20:16:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
It would be worthwhile to try to come up with some better term

[20:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
file a bug if you come up with a better term :-)

[20:16:03.0000] <Hixie>
afk

[20:17:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
OK

[20:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
(problem with the word "CDATA" is that SGML jackasses managed to ensure that there would forever be ambiguity and confusion around it - http://www.flightlab.com/~joe/sgml/cdata.html)

[05:33:01.0000] <Lachy>

[06:18:00.0000] <Lachy>
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1055214/is-there-a-way-to-make-html5-video-fullscreen

[06:19:00.0000] <Lachy>
it's a shame we don't have an API to make full screen videos

[06:19:01.0000] <Lachy>
IMHO, the arguments against doing so are bogus, since Flash can already do it

[06:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
Do the arguments include the argument that you could take a screenshot of a browser then put it in <video> then make it fullscreen and spoof the browser chrome?

[06:21:01.0000] <Lachy>
although, it's entirely possible for browsers to provide their own full screen UI

[06:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
At least Flash has a popup message saying to press Escape to leave fullscreen mode, or whatever it says

[06:22:01.0000] <Philip`>
(though irritatingly my keyboard's volume keys also cause it to leave fullscreen mode)

[06:22:02.0000] <Lachy>
sure, and there's no reason a browser couldn't do something similar

[06:23:00.0000] <Lachy>
a browser would likeliy have to show video controls when the  mouse moves anyway, which makes it even more difficult for such an attack to be successful

[06:23:01.0000] <roc>
there are clever ways to neutralize that popup message

[06:23:02.0000] <Lachy>
roc, how?

[06:24:00.0000] <roc>
I can't find the link

[06:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
if it is possible, it seems like it would have to be a bug in Flash

[06:25:01.0000] <roc>
basically you display a lot of messages on the screen that look just like Flash's one

[06:25:02.0000] <roc>
the user is totally confused and doesn't know which one to read

[06:25:03.0000] <roc>
then it all goes away and you carry on

[06:26:00.0000] <gavin_>
it's a bug in humans ;)

[06:26:01.0000] <roc>
I do think we should support fullscreen video

[06:27:00.0000] <roc>
but I think it shouldn't be under script control

[06:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
You could show some text saying "Close your eyes for five seconds, then open them again for a surprise!", then switch to fullscreen while the user's eyes are closed

[06:27:02.0000] <Lachy>
ok, file a bug with The Human Genome Project to get that fixed.

[06:28:00.0000] <roc>
alright, sleep time

[06:28:01.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, browsers would have to apply techniques similar to popup blockers, so that a script can't enter full screen without the user clicking

[06:28:02.0000] <Lachy>
(or some other user interaction)

[06:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
You could show some text saying "Close your eyes, click your mouse, wait five seconds, then open your eyes again for a surprise!", then switch to fullscreen while the user's eyes are closed

[06:29:01.0000] <Lachy>
browsers should of course provide their own native full screen UI, such as double clicking the video or selecting full screen from the context menu

[06:30:00.0000] <Lachy>
but then the user would probably move their mouse, see the video controls and realise that it's a video.

[06:31:00.0000] <Lachy>
Also, the attacker would have a hard time mimicking a user's individual desktop to to fool the user that easily

[06:33:00.0000] <Lachy>
basically, until someone can deomonstrate a practical attack vector that isn't simply hypothesising about ludicrous scenarious, I won't believe it's a serious issue

[06:37:00.0000] <Lachy>
also, the attack has to have some benefit. Simply being able to show something on a user's screen isn't really useful, unless it could somehow be used to, e.g., steal passwords or gain unauthorised access

[06:38:00.0000] <rocSleep>
I sympathize with that point of view. However, there have been several cases of people saying that, and then going ahead and standardizing behaviour which everyone ends up depending on, and then those ludicrous scenarios become reality

[06:38:01.0000] <rocSleep>
:visited-based history sniffing for example

[06:39:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'd guess a useful fullscreen mode would need to allow pages to supply custom controls, for the same reasons that non-fullscreen <video> allows custom controls

[06:39:01.0000] <Lachy>
rocSleep, not doing something because of some unproven hypothetical attack vectors that don't accually allow an attacker to do anything is silly

[06:39:02.0000] <Philip`>
in which case you could use the custom controls to interact with the fooled user

[06:39:03.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, no custom controls on full screen video

[06:40:00.0000] <Philip`>

[06:40:04.0000] <Philip`>

[06:41:00.0000] <gavin_>

[06:41:02.0000] <Lachy>

[08:29:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:40:02.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: I'm not sufficiently bored at the moment

[08:42:00.0000] <Lachy>
I wonder if anyone has implemented an IP-over-SMS service yet?

[08:44:00.0000] <Lachy>
I wonder if anyone would be bored enough to manually type in the bytes on their phone to construct an IP packet that is itself divided into 160 byte sequences?

[08:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
You could build a device out of Lego to press the buttons for you automatically

[08:45:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Surely you'd want to use base64 instead :)

[08:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
Depends on whether you want to optimise bandwidth usage or data entry time

[08:48:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, given the limitations of character entry on common mobile devices, encoding the entire packet as base64 might be the only viable option

[08:48:01.0000] <Philip`>
e.g. it'd probably be much quicker to turn off predictive typing and use base10, but you'd have to send more messages

[08:49:00.0000] <Lachy>
well, not the only viable option, since you could conceivably create your own encoding scheme

[08:49:01.0000] <Philip`>
I don't think my phone's dictionary contains SGVsbG8gd29ybGQ= so it would complain a lot when I tried to type it in

[08:49:02.0000] <Lachy>
but that would be a silly waste of time (unlike the rest of this project)

[08:50:00.0000] <Dashiva>
How about just sending one SMS per byte, having the message contain the byte value as a number 0-255?

[08:50:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Then you could have jumbo SMSes where you type more than one number in each SMS, separated by non-digits

[08:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
SMSs are a bit unreliable so you'd probably have to add sequence numbers and ACKs

[08:51:01.0000] <Philip`>
else the higher layers aren't going to cope very well with all the packet corruption

[08:53:00.0000] <Lachy>
Dashiva, once you have IP, you can then use TCP for that

[08:53:01.0000] <Philip`>
You need each SMS to contain the octet, the sequence number, and a SHA512 HMAC to ensure integrity, and then it'll be fine

[08:54:00.0000] <Dashiva>
And the ACK?

[08:55:00.0000] <Lachy>
you could get away with just the sequence number. Adding all the rest would take up too much of each message's 160 byte sequence

[08:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: SMS probably loses more than one message out of every ~1500, and TCP won't recover from 100% packet loss, so you need some layer 2 error-correction mechanism

[08:57:00.0000] <Lachy>
if you get a 100% packet loss, then the connection would simply timeout and you could assume transmission failure

[08:57:01.0000] <Philip`>
Also, TCP won't help at all with UDP applications like real-time games and Skype

[08:57:02.0000] <Lachy>
SMS-over-IP isn't designed for real time applications

[08:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: If transmission failure is pretty much guaranteed, it's a bit of a rubbish protocol

[08:58:01.0000] <Dashiva>
You could do a regular call and use voice software to read out the bytes

[08:58:02.0000] <Lachy>
oops, IP over SMS

[08:58:03.0000] <Philip`>
so we ought to design it to work around those problems

[08:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: Good thinking - the voice channel should be much more reliable than SMS

[08:59:01.0000] <Lachy>
I'd love it if someone wrote an April Fools RFC for this protocol :-)

[09:00:00.0000] <takkaria>

[09:01:03.0000] <gavin_>
