[09:03:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:06:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[09:07:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[09:07:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[09:08:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:12:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
(since it's 140 octets)

[09:13:01.0000] <Philip`>
(according to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMS#Message_size)

[09:14:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[09:14:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[09:16:00.0000] <Lachy>
well, if we're encoding the message as Base64, then normalising to NFC won't actually affect the message anyway

[09:17:00.0000] <Philip`>
The SMS spec says it's "UCS-2" and references ISO/IEC 10646

[09:18:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: what's the 8-bit encoding?

[09:18:01.0000] <takkaria>

[09:18:02.0000] <Philip`>

[09:18:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[09:18:04.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: "8 bit data is user defined"

[09:19:00.0000] <hsivonen>
ah.

[09:19:01.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: "Character table: User Specific"

[09:19:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Russian goes the 16 bit path

[09:19:03.0000] <takkaria>
yeah, it kinda relies on different phones using the same charsets

[09:19:04.0000] <hsivonen>
which is why it pays off to use ad hoc Romanizations of Russian

[09:19:05.0000] <Lachy>

[09:19:06.0000] <Lachy>

[09:19:07.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: I wouldn't assume so

[09:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
The table in http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMS#GSM shows the 7-bit characters

[09:20:01.0000] <hsivonen>
GSM had a crazy legacy of its own

[09:20:02.0000] <Philip`>
8-bit sounds like it's for data (e.g. sending photos), not text

[09:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
They've got a whole two bits for identifying the character encoding, so they could expand it with an extra choice in the future

[09:21:01.0000] <Lachy>
wow, I always thought SMS just used ASCII

[09:22:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: it was invented by people who had accented use cases

[09:23:00.0000] <Philip`>
The 7-bit thing also has escape codes to shift into a different character set, with three currently defined (Turkish, Spanish, Portugese)

[09:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you use the single shift mechanism, then sending 0x1B 0x?? will look up the second byte in the character table for the message's language (defined in a header field)

[09:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
or there's another mode which uses a language-specific table by default, and I think uses 0x1B to escape to the standard 7-bit table

[09:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
This system does sound somewhat evolved, i.e. an accumulation of hacks

[09:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me was looking at http://www.3gpp.org/ftp/Specs/archive/23_series/23.038/23038-820.zip via ftp://ftp.3gpp.org/Specs/html-info/23038.htm via http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMS#cite_note-3GPP_23.038-25

[09:38:00.0000] <hsivonen>
hmm. I guess if Google Native Client takes off, it'll further cement the position of x86 instructions as the universal byte code that future CPUs need to implement

[09:39:00.0000] <hsivonen>
/me wonders how GCC & Native Client compares to javac & HotSpot

[09:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's particularly bad if people use NaCl to do computation-intensive work (which is its main purpose) using SSE/SSE2/etc

[09:41:01.0000] <Philip`>
because they're probably not much fun to emulate efficiently on a different CPU architecture

[21:03:00.0000] <heycam>

[21:04:00.0000] <heycam>
when parsing

[21:11:00.0000] <shepazu>

[22:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie is a brave man

[23:24:00.0000] <hober>
indeed. I can't imagine going near the codec discussion

[23:38:00.0000] <shepazu>
Hixie: is heycam correct that attribute values are not parsed in a case-insensitive manner? 

[23:40:00.0000] <shepazu>
(to unwind that a bit: my understanding is that attribute values, unlike element and attribute names, are left as the case they are encountered, and not matched to different values in the DOM)

[23:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
shepazu: correct -- iirc the only processing the parser does on attribute values (other than finding their delimiters) is &entity; expansion

[23:57:00.0000] <shepazu>
Hixie: ok, good... I was worried for a moment about path commands (relative and absolute)

[23:59:00.0000] <shepazu>
now, what implications does that have on things like <text text-anchor="miDDle"/> ? will that be "error-corrected", somehow permitted as is, or fail?

[00:13:00.0000] <heycam>
shepazu, afaict, that's purely within our (svg's) purview

[00:17:00.0000] <shepazu>
heycam: then that opens up a question we should be addressing, no?

[00:17:01.0000] <heycam>
yeah i think it would be good to talk about that

[00:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
shepazu: same as in XML.

[00:18:01.0000] <heycam>
especially for consistency with style="text-anchor: miDDle", which is allowed i think

[00:18:02.0000] <shepazu>
heycam: the one place it really matters, IIRC, is path@d

[00:19:00.0000] <shepazu>
oh, and anyplace where an @id is referenced

[00:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
personally I would encourage you to keep as much as possible case-sensitive as you can

[00:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
but that if you do have anything case-insensitive, you make it work the same in XML as in text/html

[00:20:00.0000] <shepazu>
Hixie: we would certainly do the latter

[00:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
but that's just me :-)

[00:20:02.0000] <shepazu>
you've argued for case-insensitivity for element and attribute names... this seems a bit inconsistent

[12:59:00.0000] <ezyang>

[13:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
$ echo '섞聽靑孃숍訊昱穿刷奄剔굉낑섞昌侄從없' | iconv -t iso-2022-kr

[13:00:01.0000] <Philip`>
)C</title><script>alert(123)</script>x

[13:00:02.0000] <ezyang>
whoa :-P 

[13:01:00.0000] <ezyang>
Ok, so this only affects sites that let you set the page's output encoding 

[13:01:01.0000] <Philip`>
so Yahoo encodes the text into that string of bytes, and Chrome doesn't support iso-2022-kr so it decodes as iso-8859-1 (or utf-8 or something) and executes the script

[13:01:02.0000] <Philip`>
(All other browsers do support iso-2022-kr, as far as I can tell)

[13:01:03.0000] <ezyang>
That's... a chrome bug 

[13:02:00.0000] <ezyang>
Also, I still don't understand why search engines let you twiddle the output encoding 

[13:02:01.0000] <Philip`>
It's not a bug for a browser to not support a relatively obscure encoding

[13:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
Even if it did, you might be able to find aliases that are supported by a server but not by the browser

[13:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
Twiddling the output encoding does seem like a pretty stupid idea

[13:03:02.0000] <Philip`>
but Google and Yahoo both allow it, so I guess they've got reasons

[13:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
Ultraseek allows it too, and didn't even forbid EBCDIC when I last tried it, so you can XSS it that way too

[13:04:01.0000] <ezyang>
So, the only good reason is accessibility 

[13:05:00.0000] <ezyang>
For those pauvre browsers that don't support UTF-8 

[13:05:01.0000] <ezyang>
Search engines like Google have a weird notion of what accessible needs to be 

[13:06:00.0000] <ezyang>
I wonder what UTF-8 penetration is these days 

[13:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
It doesn't help those browsers unless the users intentionally follow a link with the query parameter that sets the output encoding

[13:07:01.0000] <ezyang>
I thought that Google would do tricky user agent detection? 

[13:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
If it was doing that, why would it put the output encoding in the query parameter instead of doing the tricky user agent detection when serving the results page?

[15:29:00.0000] <Sirisian>
Something I noticed. I've been looking through the Editor's Draft for the HTML 5 stuff. It has a section for the context menus and it says "When an element's context menu is requested [...] the UA must fire a simple event called contextmenu that bubbles and is cancelable at the element for which the menu was requested." I was going to post in the forum with a long post, but why isn't this extended to mouse up and mouse down 

[15:29:01.0000] <Sirisian>
to set a standard for preventDefault for like middle click events by the browser. (Making a standard that says it should be "cancelable").

[15:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
there is another spec to handle the actual user interaction events

[15:30:01.0000] <Hixie>
like mousedown and mouseup

[15:30:02.0000] <Hixie>
separate from html5

[15:30:03.0000] <Hixie>
(it applies to things like svg also)

[15:30:04.0000] <Hixie>
that spec hasn't been written yet though

[15:30:05.0000] <Sirisian>
You mean for how browsers should react and work with them?

[15:30:06.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[15:30:07.0000] <Sirisian>
oh is there a link? I must have missed it

[15:30:08.0000] <Hixie>
and how they should be cancelable and stuff

[15:30:09.0000] <Hixie>
it doesn't exist yet
